posts.html:
NodeJS

We are living in a world where NodeJS is gaining market share at a rapid pace and is now making significant inroads in the enterprise.

Major companies are announcing shifts to Node as a key component of their web development.

MongoDB

MongoDB is definitely one of the most popular. It stores its data in a format called BSON, which is just a binary representation of JSON. MongoDB also uses JavaScript as its native query language.

JavaScript

With these inventions, suddenly it became possible to build an entire web applications using only JavaScript across all the tiers. Each tier still requires significantly different coding paradigms, but now at least the language can be the same.

MEAN App from scratch

In this course we are going to learn how to build an application with the MEAN Stack.

We will build a realistic application end to end, starting from absolutely nothing, just an empty folder and develop it line by line.

  1. We create our walking skeleton which will be every layer from the client all the way through to the database.
  2. Next, we'll get right to business by getting our application out on the web. We'll learn how to deploy it to Heroku, a popular and free hosting service.
  3. Then, we'll go back to the code and lay the ground work for our user interface.
  4. The next step will be to implement authentication and authorization for our application. We'll use the passport module for this, which is one of the more popular Node modules for authentication.
  5. After that we will set up tests for our client-side code. We won't do a bunch of testing, but we will get it set up.
  6. After that, we'll create entities using a RESTful interface by implementing our sign-up page to create new users.
  7. In the next module we'll implement the user profile page, which will teach us all about updating data with the MEAN Stack.
  8. The next module will be a list page, which we will use to learn about sorting, filtering, and caching data.
  9. And in our last module, we'll implement a details page, which will teach us about selecting and caching single entities.

At this point we will have a complete application that will have all the pieces of a real application and could easily be used as a starting point for any kind of application with relatively few changes.

posts.markdown: ###### Walking Skeleton ###### > A "**walking skeleton**" is a tiny implementation of the system that performs a small end-to-end function. > It need not use the final architecture, but it should link together the main architectural components. > The architecture and the functionality can then evolve in parallel. First, it is end to end, which for us that means **database to client**. Second, it should involve all the main architectural components so we should involve every item from the main acronym, **Mongo**, **Express**, **Angular**, and **Node**, and the three pieces, **client**, **server**, and **database** should be involved. Third, this approach allows us to **develop our app in an iterative manner** so it can slowly grow and we can constantly see new pieces that are added, working as part of the system rather than waiting days or even longer. That helps us know sooner if we need to change our course or rethink an approach. Nothing that I do in this module will be specific to our application, except for the name, so this can be a starting point for any **MEAN Stack** application. ![Module Agenda](/content/images/2015/03/module-agenda.png) ## Steps to creating the walking skeleton: ## 1. We will start it off by creating a **package.json** file for our project, which will **store which modules our Node application depends on**. 2. Then we will **add Git** so that we can get our project under source control and also deploy our code to **Heroku**. 3. After that we will use **Bower to install our client-side dependencies** and you will see how easy and convenient it is to manage your client-side dependencies with Bower. 4. Then we will **create the Node application** by creating our first server-side JavaScript file. 5. After that we will **add Stylus** to our project, which will compile our CSS for us. 6. Next we will **create a layout** for our server-side views. 7. The next step will be **creating our client-side Angular app**. This will be a super simple application, but it will still use Angular to render some data. 8. Finally, we will **add MongoDB** to our application and we will display some data from our database on our web page. --- VersionsGit and package.json
posts.html:
Walking Skeleton

A "walking skeleton" is a tiny implementation of the system that performs a small end-to-end function.

It need not use the final architecture, but it should link together the main architectural components.

The architecture and the functionality can then evolve in parallel.

First, it is end to end, which for us that means database to client.

Second, it should involve all the main architectural components so we should involve every item from the main acronym, Mongo, Express, Angular, and Node, and the three pieces, client, server, and database should be involved.

Third, this approach allows us to develop our app in an iterative manner so it can slowly grow and we can constantly see new pieces that are added, working as part of the system rather than waiting days or even longer.

That helps us know sooner if we need to change our course or rethink an approach.

Nothing that I do in this module will be specific to our application, except for the name, so this can be a starting point for any MEAN Stack application.

Steps to creating the walking skeleton:

  1. We will start it off by creating a package.json file for our project, which will store which modules our Node application depends on.

  2. Then we will add Git so that we can get our project under source control and also deploy our code to Heroku.

  3. After that we will use Bower to install our client-side dependencies and you will see how easy and convenient it is to manage your client-side dependencies with Bower.

  4. Then we will create the Node application by creating our first server-side JavaScript file.

  5. After that we will add Stylus to our project, which will compile our CSS for us.

  6. Next we will create a layout for our server-side views.

  7. The next step will be creating our client-side Angular app. This will be a super simple application, but it will still use Angular to render some data.

  8. Finally, we will add MongoDB to our application and we will display some data from our database on our web page.

VersionsGit and package.json

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack: Client-side Dependencies with Bower
posts.markdown:
## Install bower ## ```bash $ npm install bower -g ``` ## Add Express and Jade ## ```bash $ npm install --save express jade ``` ## Setup "public" and "server" directories ## ```bash $ mkdir server $ mkdir public $ ls > README.md package.json public server ``` Before we install our dependencies though, we need to have a place for those dependencies to go so it's time to discuss our top-level folders in our project. #### The "**server**" directory #### > **Server-side folder** where you put your **Node** source files plus our **Jade** views and our **client-side partials**. Normally named "app", where I'm going put my **client-side partials** inside of my "**server**" directory is because since we're using **Angular**, we're not gonna have very many server side views and I want to be able to author my **client-side views** in **Jade**, which means that **Node** is actually going to have to process them as views and can't just deliver them untouched the way it would with **HTML** files. That means those **client-side partials** are going to need to reside in the same directory as my **server-side views**. #### The "**public**" directory #### > **Client-side folder** where you put all of your public **assets** such as **CSS**, images, and **JavaScript** files. Now that we've got the folder that's going to contain our **client-side dependencies**, before we can begin installing them, we need to do one more thing and create a **.bowerrc** file. ## Create a .bowerrc file ## ```bash $ touch .bowerrc $ vim .bowerrc ``` .bowerrc 
{
  "directory": "public/vendor"
}
This file will tell Bower to install our client-side dependencies into a public folder named "**vendor**". ## Create bower.json file ## ```bash $ bower init ? name: MEAN-myApp ? version: 1.0.0 ? description: ? main file: ? what types of modules does this package expose?: node ? keywords: ? authors: Edwin Estrada ? license: MIT ? homepage: ? set currently installed components as dependencies?: No ? add commonly ignored files to ignore list?: No ? would you like to mark this package as private which prevents it from being accidentally published to the registry?: Yes { name: 'MEAN-myApp', version: '1.0.0', authors: [ 'Edwin Estrada ' ], license: 'MIT', private: true } ? Looks good?: Yes ``` ## Install client-side dependencies ## ```bash $ bower install jquery --save $ bower install toastr --save $ bower install angular angular-resource angular-route --save ``` ## Verify client-dependencies ## bower.json 
{
  "name": "MEAN-myApp",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "authors": [
    "Edwin Estrada "
  ],
  "license": "MIT",
  "private": true,
  "dependencies": {
    "jquery": "~2.1.3",
    "toastr": "~2.1.0",
    "angular": "~1.3.13",
    "angular-resource": "~1.3.13",
    "angular-route": "~1.3.13"
  }
}
--- Git & package.jsonNode app

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack: Creating the Node Application
posts.markdown:
## Add Express module to 'server.js': ## ```bash $ touch server.js $ vim server.js ``` server.js 
var express = require('express');

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

app.set('views', __dirname + '/server/views');
app.set('view engine', 'jade');
**[1]** The first thing we'll do in this file is bring in the **Express** module. This gives us the ability to begin working with **Express** and create our **Express** application. **[3]** The next thing I want is an **environment variable** that I can use in order to determine whether or not I'm in **development mode** or **production mode**. **Node** already has an **environment variable** that's contained inside of the **process.env.NODE_ENV**. This is going to contain what the environment if it's been set by **Node**. The problem is, if you don't set your **Node** environment, then it doesn't have a good default value, in this case "**development**". **[5]** create our actual Express application **[7]** I need to configure is my **view engine**, so I'm going to set the views property, and I'm going to set that to the path where I'm going to hold my views. **[8]** I also need to set what the view engine will be. --- ###### Routing in Express ###### Now in order to create a **route** for this purpose in **Express**, I'll just use the **app.get** function and typically on something like this you **specify your route with just the forward slash, indicating whenever they go to the root of the website**, this is what you want to have happen. server.js 
var express = require('express');

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

app.set('views', __dirname + '/server/views');
app.set('view engine', 'jade');

app.get('*', function(req, res){  
  res.render('index');
});
**[10]** Added a route that delivers my index page specified by the asterisk, and I also have to give it a callback that will take in the request and response objects **[11]** Told the application to render my index view Instead of this route, I'm actually going to specify the **asterisk**. > The **asterisk** will match **all routes**. That means that **any request** that gets to this point is going to be **handled by this route**. That includes JavaScript requests, CSS requests, image requests, everything. Now the reason I'm going to specify this route is because **I want the application to deliver my index page whenever any request is made that I don't already have an existing path for**. posts.html:
NPM install modules

$ npm install stylus morgan body-parser --save
Setup Stylus Middleware

server.js 

var express = require('express'),  
  stylus = require('stylus');

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

function compile(str, path){  
  return stylus(str).set('filename', path);
}

app.set('views', __dirname + '/server/views');  
app.set('view engine', 'jade');  
app.use(stylus.middleware(  
  {
    src: __dirname + '/public',
    compile: compile
  }
));
app.use(express.static(__dirname + '/public'));

app.get('*', function(req, res){  
  res.render('index');
});

var port = 3030;  
app.listen(port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + port + '...');

[2] In order for an application to run we're going to need to be able to serve up CSS files. Require the Stylus library.

[8-10] Compile function that gets used by the middleware.

[14] Pass the Stylus middleware a configuration object

[16] Configuration object's source, which will be our current directory plus the public folder

[17] Configuration object's compile function

[20] Set up static routing to our public directory using a very typical configuration for your static files.

This tells Express that any time any requests come in that match up to a file inside of the public directory, to go ahead and serve the file.

So for example, if a request comes in for \favicon.ico, then Express will look inside of the public directory for the filed called favicon.ico.

By extension if we want to get our angular file, a request would need to come into '/vendor/angular/angular.js" instead of 'public/vendor/angular/angular.js".

This is why our .bowerrc sets the client-side dependencies to be installed in 'public/vendor/'.

Morgan(logger) & Body Parser

}

posts.html:
Create the first client-side JS file

This will be the main entry point to our Angular application and that's going to go inside of the "app" directory and the file name is going to be "app.js".

$ mkdir public/app
$ touch public/app/app.js

Define our Angular module

public/app/app.js 

angular.module('app', ['ngResource', 'ngRoute']);

angular.module('app').config(function($routeProvider, $locationProvider){  
  $locationProvider.html5Mode({
    enabled: true,
    requireBase: false
  });
  $routeProvider
    .when('/', { templateUrl: '/partials/main', controller: 'mainController' });

});

angular.module('app').controller('mainController', function($scope){  
  $scope.myVar = "Snaaaaaakkkke!";
});

[1] Define the angular module and the dependencies on the ngResource and ngRoute modules.

[3] Define our client-side routes inside of this file by calling the config function and we'll bring in our $routeProvider and we'll also bring in the $locationProvider.

[4] Use $locationProvider to turn on HTML 5 mode for routing.

[5] We'll use our $routeProvider to define our routes.

[6] Start out with just one route that goes to the root of our application.

Our template URL will be "/partials/main" and right now we don't have a server-side route for that, but we'll create one in just a second.

Preview of server-side route

    res.render('common/partials/' + req.params.partialPath);
  });

posts.html:
We're going to retreive some data from our MongoDB database and displaying it on our index page.

Create a message schema with Mongoose

We'll retrieve one of those messages from the database and display that message on our index page.

server.js 

var express = require('express'),  
  stylus = require('stylus'),
  logger = require('morgan'),
  bodyParser = require('body-parser'),
  mongoose = require('mongoose');

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

function compile(str, path){  
  return stylus(str).set('filename', path);
}

app.set('views', __dirname + '/server/views');  
app.set('view engine', 'jade');  
app.use(logger('dev'));  
app.use(bodyParser());  
app.use(stylus.middleware(  
  {
    src: __dirname + '/public',
    compile: compile
  }
));
app.use(express.static(__dirname + '/public'));

mongoose.connect('mongodb://localhost/mydatabase');  
var db = mongoose.connection;  
db.on('error', console.error.bind(console, 'connection error...'));  
db.once('open', function callback(){  
  console.log('mydatabase db opened');
});
var messageSchema = mongoose.Schema({message: String});  
var Message = mongoose.model('Message', messageSchema);  
var mongoMessage;  
Message.findOne().exec(function(err, messageDocFound){  
  mongoMessage = messageDocFound.message;
});

app.get('/partials/:partialPath', function(req, res){  
  res.render('partials/' + req.params.partialPath);
});

app.get('*', function(req, res){  
  res.render('index', {
    mongoMessage: mongoMessage
  });
});

var port = 3030;

#### Introduction #### The term **NoSQL** is commonly used to describe a group of emerging non-relational database systems. NoSQL databases have grown in popularity as of late, but of these **MongoDB** is the clear favorite. I like to think of a database as an **empty filing cabinet**, whether that be a relational database system such as **SQL Server** or **MySQL**, or a NoSQL database such as **MongoDB**. ![](/content/images/2015/03/filing-cabinet.png) When filing data in a relational database things are structured and rule based, every record must match the tables at schema design. ![](/content/images/2015/03/rule-based.png) This is not the case with MongoDB, simply, you can put whatever you want into that filing cabinet, that freedom is what causes some developers to be nervous about using NoSQL databases such as MongoDB, they're used to having the database set the rules. The goal of this course is to give you the building blocks needed to **build great web applications using Mongoose to easily store data in, and retrieve documents from MongoDB in a structured manner**. ![Course Goals](/content/images/2015/03/course-goals.png) You can still think of this as a filing cabinet full of documents, but one that has some structure and rules to it, I say some rules because, well with MongoDB you still have the freedom to store whatever you want, even if you are using Mongoose. The Node.js application that we will be developing throughout this course will effectively illustrate: 1. **Setting up a Mongoose schema** - **Building a model from that schema** - **Validating data**
>> Prerequisites

Introduction

The term NoSQL is commonly used to describe a group of emerging non-relational database systems. NoSQL databases have grown in popularity as of late, but of these MongoDB is the clear favorite.

I like to think of a database as an empty filing cabinet, whether that be a relational database system such as SQL Server or MySQL, or a NoSQL database such as MongoDB.

When filing data in a relational database things are structured and rule based, every record must match the tables at schema design.

This is not the case with MongoDB, simply, you can put whatever you want into that filing cabinet, that freedom is what causes some developers to be nervous about using NoSQL databases such as MongoDB, they're used to having the database set the rules.

The goal of this course is to give you the building blocks needed to build great web applications using Mongoose to easily store data in, and retrieve documents from MongoDB in a structured manner.

You can still think of this as a filing cabinet full of documents, but one that has some structure and rules to it, I say some rules because, well with MongoDB you still have the freedom to store whatever you want, even if you are using Mongoose.

The Node.js application that we will be developing throughout this course will effectively illustrate:

  1. Setting up a Mongoose schema
  2. Building a model from that schema
  3. Validating data

posts.title: Intro to Mongoose for Node.js and MongoDB: Course Introduction - Why Mongoose?
posts.markdown: #### Why Mongoose? #### So why use Mongoose? If you have dug into MongoDB at all, or if you've seen a demo of it, the chances are that you've either used or watched someone else use a native MongoDB driver. There are official MongoDB drivers for many development languages such as C++, C#, Java, Perl, PHP, Python, Ruby, and of course Node.js. There are also several community supported drivers for various other languages as well, so why then would we just not use the native Node.js MongoDB driver? Sometimes you may find that you should, but a quick visit to the online MongoDB documents may give us the answers we're looking for here. > Because MongoDB is so easy to use; the basic Node.js driver can be the best solution for many applications. > However, if you need validations, associations, and other high-level data modeling functions, then an Object Document Mapper may be helpful. > **Mongoose is the officially supported ODM for Node.js**, it has a thriving open source community, and it includes advanced schema-based features such as an async validation, casting, object life-cycle management, pseudo-joins, and rich query builder support. So there's not a basic simple one answer here why you should or should not use Mongoose in your application, but as you move forward in this course my hope is that you will gain enough knowledge, some of the reasons maybe that are listed here to know when to use Mongoose, and when it may be best to use a native MongoDB driver. Why Mongoose?

So why use Mongoose? If you have dug into MongoDB at all, or if you've seen a demo of it, the chances are that you've either used or watched someone else use a native MongoDB driver. There are official MongoDB drivers for many development languages such as C++, C#, Java, Perl, PHP, Python, Ruby, and of course Node.js.

There are also several community supported drivers for various other languages as well, so why then would we just not use the native Node.js MongoDB driver? Sometimes you may find that you should, but a quick visit to the online MongoDB documents may give us the answers we're looking for here.

Because MongoDB is so easy to use; the basic Node.js driver can be the best solution for many applications.

However, if you need validations, associations, and other high-level data modeling functions, then an Object Document Mapper may be helpful.

Mongoose is the officially supported ODM for Node.js, it has a thriving open source community, and it includes advanced schema-based features such as an async validation, casting, object life-cycle management, pseudo-joins, and rich query builder support.

So there's not a basic simple one answer here why you should or should not use Mongoose in your application, but as you move forward in this course my hope is that you will gain enough knowledge, some of the reasons maybe that are listed here to know when to use Mongoose, and when it may be best to use a native MongoDB driver.

posts.markdown:
#### Demo #### Now that we have node.js installed, "Node Packaged Modules" or as it's also commonly referred to as, the **node package manager (NPM)** comes along for the ride. We can use NPM to install **express**, the **express generator**, our view engine of choice, **Swig**, and naturally the package this course is about, **Mongoose**. We're going to use NPM to install express with **-g** or **--global** appended to this command. It installs the current package context as a global package, meaning that it will be available to you anywhere on your system, and that's what we want to do. ```bash $ npm install express --global ``` Since I already have Express installed I'm going to cancel this, and let's take a look at how to use NPM to install Express Generator. ```bash $ npm install express-generator -g ``` Let's test out the Express Generator and make sure that it was installed correctly and running. ```bash $ express --help ``` ![Express Help](/content/images/2015/03/Hogan-3.png) Here in Express help notice the **-H** option here for Hogan, the HJS view engine. Of the supported view engines directly offered by the generator, Hogan is the closest to what we want, Swig, so we'll start with that one and make some minor changes and adjustments in a moment. First we'll set up a directory for our project, and change to that directory. ```bash $ mkdir standup $ cd standup ``` Now we're going to run the express generator to create the scaffold express website using the Hogan view engine. We're going to type in Express with the option **-H**. ```bash $ express -H ``` ![express -H](/content/images/2015/03/express-generator-hogan.png) The Express Generator has stubbed out a nice Express app for us to work with, this would be a good time to open our project in the editor that we will be using for the remainder of this course. ###### Package.json ###### Let's open up and discuss the contents of our **package.json** file. In the dependency section here you can see the Node.js packages that the generator setup for us, these packages however, have not yet been installed. To do that we'll need to run NPM install. We'll open the terminal and run 'npm install' to install all of the node packages found in the dependency section. ```bash $ npm install ``` > Now you will notice that we have the node modules folder in our project. That's great we're getting really close to having the foundation laid out for our demo application. One thing to make note of while we're here in the **package.json** file is to take a look at the script section, notice that the script start calls the node command with bin/www. The command **npm start** will run this script, which is the same thing as typing in **node ./bin/www** at the command prompt. Let's test run our application now and make sure that everything's working as expected. ```bash $ npm start ``` Go to [localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000/) ![Application Running](/content/images/2015/03/npm_start.png) It's not much to look at yet, but our Express site is working. ###### Adding Swig ###### Back in the editor let's wire up our view engine Swig. We're going to need to first install Swig, so let's type in **npm install swig**, and make sure that we save that to our package.json. ```bash $ npm install swig --save ``` Now on the app.js file we'll change the view engine from **hjs** to **html**. app.js 
var express = require('express');
var path = require('path');
var favicon = require('serve-favicon');
var logger = require('morgan');
var cookieParser = require('cookie-parser');
var bodyParser = require('body-parser');

var routes = require('./routes/index');
var users = require('./routes/users');

var app = express();

// assign the swig view engine to .html files...
var swig = require('swig');
app.engine('html', swig.renderFile);

// view engine setup
app.set('views', path.join(__dirname, 'views'));
app.set('view engine', 'html');

// uncomment after placing your favicon in /public
//app.use(favicon(__dirname + '/public/favicon.ico'));
app.use(logger('dev'));
app.use(bodyParser.json());
app.use(bodyParser.urlencoded({ extended: false }));
app.use(cookieParser());
app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public')));
**[#15]** Next we'll assign Swig as our view engine to handle the HTML files. Now we need to rename the .hjs files in our views folder to .html. ```bash $ mv views/error.hjs views/error.html $ mv views/index.hjs views/index.html ``` Since we're not using Hogan or hjs we can uninstall that. ```bash $ npm uninstall hjs --save ``` Let's test out our scaffold site one more time now to verify everything is still working as expected, we'll run NPM start from the terminal again. ```bash $ npm start ``` Go to [localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000/) ![Application Running](/content/images/2015/03/npm_start.png) Alright, looks like we're still up and running, that's good news. We've successfully laid out the foundational pieces of our **Virtual Stand-up Meeting Notes** application, but we have a lot more to do.

We're going to use NPM to install express with -g or --global appended to this command. It installs the current package context as a global package, meaning that it will be available to you anywhere on your system, and that's what we want to do.

$ npm install express --global

Since I already have Express installed I'm going to cancel this, and let's take a look at how to use NPM to install Express Generator.

$ npm install express-generator -g

Let's test out the Express Generator and make sure that it was installed correctly and running.

$ express --help

Here in Express help notice the -H option here for Hogan, the HJS view engine.

Of the supported view engines directly offered by the generator, Hogan is the closest to what we want, Swig, so we'll start with that one and make some minor changes and adjustments in a moment.

First we'll set up a directory for our project, and change to that directory.

$ mkdir standup
$ cd standup

Now we're going to run the express generator to create the scaffold express website using the Hogan view engine. We're going to type in Express with the option -H.

$ express -H

The Express Generator has stubbed out a nice Express app for us to work with, this would be a good time to open our project in the editor that we will be using for the remainder of this course.

Package.json

Let's open up and discuss the contents of our package.json file.

In the dependency section here you can see the Node.js packages that the generator setup for us, these packages however, have not yet been installed. To do that we'll need to run NPM install. We'll open the terminal and run 'npm install' to install all of the node packages found in the dependency section.

$ npm install

Now you will notice that we have the node modules folder in our project.

That's great we're getting really close to having the foundation laid out for our demo application.

One thing to make note of while we're here in the package.json file is to take a look at the script section, notice that the script start calls the node command with bin/www. The command npm start will run this script, which is the same thing as typing in node ./bin/www at the command prompt.

Let's test run our application now and make sure that everything's working as expected.

$ npm start

Go to localhost:3000

It's not much to look at yet, but our Express site is working.

Adding Swig

Back in the editor let's wire up our view engine Swig.

We're going to need to first install Swig, so let's type in npm install swig, and make sure that we save that to our package.json.

$ npm install swig --save

Now on the app.js file we'll change the view engine from hjs to html.

app.js 

var express = require('express');  
var path = require('path');  
var favicon = require('serve-favicon');  
var logger = require('morgan');  
var cookieParser = require('cookie-parser');  
var bodyParser = require('body-parser');

var routes = require('./routes/index');  
var users = require('./routes/users');

var app = express();

// assign the swig view engine to .html files...
var swig = require('swig');  
app.engine('html', swig.renderFile);

// view engine setup
app.set('views', path.join(__dirname, 'views'));  
app.set('view engine', 'html');

// uncomment after placing your favicon in /public
//app.use(favicon(__dirname + '/public/favicon.ico'));
app.use(logger('dev'));  
app.use(bodyParser.json());  
app.use(bodyParser.urlencoded({ extended: false }));  
app.use(cookieParser());  
app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, 'public')));

[#15] Next we'll assign Swig as our view engine to handle the HTML files.

Now we need to rename the .hjs files in our views folder to .html.

$ mv views/error.hjs views/error.html
$ mv views/index.hjs views/index.html

Since we're not using Hogan or hjs we can uninstall that.

$ npm uninstall hjs --save

Let's test out our scaffold site one more time now to verify everything is still working as expected, we'll run NPM start from the terminal again.

$ npm start

Go to localhost:3000

Alright, looks like we're still up and running, that's good news.

We've successfully laid out the foundational pieces of our Virtual Stand-up Meeting Notes application, but we have a lot more to do.

posts.title: Wordpress Development: Migration Checklist
posts.markdown:
###### Welcome to your migration checklist ######

Work through the below tasks to get your site migrated to WP Engine.

Keep track of what you've completed by checking the boxes next to each task.

Before getting started, gather your login information to access the following:

- Prior hosting provider
- WordPress Admin Dashboard
- DNS Registrar

---

### Setup ###
###### Start by setting up your WP Engine SFTP credentials and your site's domain name. ######

<input type="checkbox"> Setup SFTP</input>

In this section, you will set up your permissions to access our server's file system via Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP).

Username: ?
Password: ?
Server: ?

<input type="checkbox"> Enter your current site's domain name</input>

This section allows you to link domains to the WordPress installation. Be attentive to the www part. Check your live website to see if it uses www in front of the domain name. Most people prefer domain.com. If such is the case, add domain.com to the Primary Domain line, and then add www.domain.com to the optional Redirect line.
You can add URL redirects, extra domains, and domain redirects in the launch stage.

---

### Update ###
###### Create a backup of your current site, update WordPress Core, plugins and themes. ######

<input type="checkbox"> Back up your site with your current host</input>

Prior to making any changes, we strongly recommend you backup your website with your current host. This will mean you can restore your website if your updates cause problems.

A backup of your website consists of the database (posts, comments, site options, etc.) and the wp-content folder (themes, plugins, and media).

<input type="checkbox"> Make sure you are not using disallowed plugins</input>

Because some plugins are poorly coded or incompatible with WP Engine's platform, we don't allow them on our hosted sites. You can use our WP Engine Ready plugin to verify your site's readiness for migration. This plugin will check your current version of WordPress Core, detect any disallowed plugins, and also highlight any incompatible functions that your site's themes or plugins are using.

Most disallowed plugins enable caching or backup functionality. WP Engine offers both as part of our platform, so you have less to manage on your side.

[Disallowed plugin list](http://wpengine.com/support/disallowed-plugins/?utm_campaign=migration_checklist&utm_source=portal&utm_medium=update)

<input type="checkbox"> Update plugins, themes, and WordPress Core</input>

We strongly recommend that you update WordPress Core, plugins, and themes prior to migration to ensure your site functions properly after migration. This can also prevent common migration issues associated with outdated software.

Note: Updating older themes and plugins may cause issues with your site

1. Go to the Updates section of WordPress Admin for your current site.
2. Update all plugins, themes and WordPress Core.
3. Review your site to ensure everything looks and functions properly.
4. Troubleshoot and resolve any issues associated with the update.

---

### Export ###
###### Here we'll gather your current site's files to be moved. ######

<input type="checkbox"> Export database from your prior hosting provider</input>

This file contains instructions for our server's database language (SQL) to create the posts, comments, and options from your old host on our host. The most common way of accessing your database file is through your host's phpMyAdmin. If you need assistance locating your database, contact your current host provider.

1. Log in to your current host provider's cPanel
2. Access phpMyAdmin
3. Select the site database, on the left, you wish to migrate
4. Click Export on the top navigation bar
5. Under Export Method, select Custom
6. Under Table(s), click Select All
7. Under Object creation options, make sure only the following options are checked as shown below...
8. Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click Go to save the database to your desktop as a file (.sql)

![Options checked](/content/images/2015/03/db_step.png)

<input type="checkbox"> Download your wp-content folder</input>

The wp-content folder contains your plugins, themes, and media from your site. Depending on how big your site is, this can take a while -- sometimes up to a couple of hours. Need an SFTP client? FileZilla works on all operating systems.

1. Log into your current host via their portal or FTP client.
2. Access Export content step2
3. Download/copy the "wp-content" folder to your computer's desktop. (Select zip option if available. If not, once the wp-content folder has been downloaded, make sure to zip this folder before uploading to save uploading time and avoid corruption errors.)

---

### Import ###
###### Now let's import your files to WP Engine. ######

<input type="checkbox"> Import your database to WP Engine.</input>

This task will walk you through the steps you need to take in order to clear your current default database and seamlessly import your site's database to WP Engine. If you encounter issues importing your database, please contact Support.

1. Access your new install's phpMyAdmin
2. Click on the database on the far left titled wp_NEWBLOG
3. Halfway down the page, click Check All to select all tables, and select Drop from the dropdown menu.
4. Click Yes to confirm
5. Click the Import step5 tab
6. Click Choose File
7. Select your database that you previously exported wp_dalelari.sql
8. Click Go, located at the bottom of the page
9. Once you have successfully imported your database, check your table prefixes. If they do not start with "wp_", please visit Changing A Table Prefix for instructions on how to make the necessary changes.

![Check all and Drop](/content/images/2015/03/checkall-drop.png)

![Table Prefix](/content/images/2015/03/table-prefixes.png)

<input type="checkbox"> Import your wp-content folder to WP Engine</input>

1. Using an SFTP client, log into your new WP server. Need an SFTP client? FileZilla works on all operating systems.
2. Upload your local copy of the "wp-content" zipped folder to the WP Engine server. Do not forget to zip this folder before exporting to save uploading time and avoid corruption errors.
3. Once the transfer was completed successfully, click on the button below to open a support ticket and extract the files.

```bash
Host: sftp://dalelari.wpengine.com
Username: dalelari
Password: Same as you set up in step 1
Port: 22
```

---

posts.title: Node.js: Creating Demo APIs with json-server
posts.markdown:
###### Create the folder for the new project. ###### Terminal ```bash $ mkdir demo-server $ cd demo-server $ git init ``` ###### Install JSON Server. ###### I'm going to use npm to install globally JSON's server. I could use this anywhere in my system, but I'm just going to use it in this current directory. Also, I'm going to create a file called 'db.json'. Terminal ```bash $ npm install -g json-server $ touch db.json $ vim db.json ``` Inside 'db.json' I will describe it as an object with an array of people. It's simply going to be ID zero and name John. db.json 
{
  "people" : [
    {
      "id": 0,
      "name": "John"
    }
  ]
}
With this JSON file I can go ahead and type as shown below and this will launch JSON server. Terminal ```bash $ json-server db.json ``` So if you **[http://localhost:3000/](http://localhost:3000)** you can see it gives you a nice little page here saying you can load people. ![Browser](/content/images/2015/03/browser.png) It gives me the array with the single person. OR You can just launch the DB link which will give you the entire JSON database. ###### RESTful API: GET Request ###### I'm going to use a Chrome app called **Postman**. This REST client allows me to put in the URL I want to use which is **[http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000)** and the path I want to use, which is **people**. **[http://localhost:3000/people](http://localhost:3000/people)** I'll go ahead and just make a **GET** request of this which will return just what we saw before. ![GET Request](/content/images/2015/03/Postman1.png) ###### RESTful API: POST Request ###### If I want to **POST** to people, I'll say, "POST, make a new request," which I'm going to set to a Header to '**Content-type**' with Value '**application/json**' with a raw text of '**{"name": "Henry"}**'. ![POST Request](/content/images/2015/03/Postman2.png) Then when I hit run you'll see it will post Henry. I can post another one, so it will be number two. Once I get this again and hit run, you can see I get John, Henry, Henry since I ran post twice. Now you can see this last guy has the same name, so let's go ahead and update him. ###### RESTful API: PUT Request ###### We'll go to the path of two here, so slash two. ![Path 2](/content/images/2015/03/Postman3.png) We'll say **PUT**, and then in my request we'll change the name to Frank. We'll run this. ![PUT Request](/content/images/2015/03/Postman4-1.png) If I go ahead and I get the entire array of people, you can see now I have John, Henry, and Frank. ![Entire Array of People](/content/images/2015/03/Postman5.png) We really don't have that much data to work with, so let's go ahead and fake out a whole bunch of data to play around with. ###### Taking a snapshot ###### At this point if I were to shut down my JSON server it would actually lose all of the changes I've made because it's just keeping it in memory. If you type **'S'** and hit enter, it saves a snapshot that shows all of the changes I made. Then it backs up my previous file named this. Terminal ```bash $ ls | grep '^db' db-1426368902918.json db.json ``` We now have: - **db.json** as the newest snapshot - **db-123456789.json** as the original copy from the start. ###### Faking data ###### Now we'll create a JavaScript file which we'll just call '**generate.js**'. Terminal ```bash $ touch generate.js $ vim generate.js ``` This is going require us to **export a function which returns some sort of object**. 
module.exports = function () {
  return {}; // Object
}
Whatever object we get back is going to be used as that JSON data. The tools I want to use for this, I'm going to go ahead and say, "**npm install Faker and Lo-Dash**". Terminal ```bash $ npm install faker lodash ``` This will help me easily generate this data that I want to generate. generate.js 
module.exports = function(){
  var faker = require("faker");
  var _ = require("lodash");
  return {
    people: _.times(100, function (n) {
      return {
        id: n,
        name: faker.name.findName(),
        avatar: faker.internet.avatar()
      }
    })
  }
}
**[2]** required **faker** **[3]** required **lodash** **[4]** going to **return** an object **[5]** for the people we're going to use lo-dash's **times 100**. This argument here is going to be the index as it loops through 100 times and produce an array of objects. **[7]** return an **ID** of **n** **[8]** return a random name with **faker.name.findname()** **[8]** return a random profile picture with **faker.internet.avatar()** More details on faker.js at **[http://marak.com/faker.js/](http://marak.com/faker.js/)**. Now all I have to do is say, "**json-server**" and then target my '**generate.js**' script. Terminal ```bash $ json-server generate.js ``` ###### Seeing new data ###### If I open my RESTful Web Services and I run a get request, you can see it returns all of this data, a hundred different people. ![Fake Data](/content/images/2015/03/Postman5-1.png) All of this data I could loop through, query, post, update, delete, all that sort of stuff. You can even, like I said, query. If I say, "**[http://localhost:3000/people?q=Sven](http://localhost:3000/people?q=Sven)**" hit enter. ![Querying](/content/images/2015/03/Postman6.png) It's going to return everyone named Sven, which was that second guy that I noted. > You'll have a ton of data to work with for any demo you want to build.

posts.title: Node.js: What are CommonJS Modules?
posts.markdown:
###### Managing multiple source files ###### Web development has undergone some pretty radical changes over the last several years, not the least of which was how you manage multiple source files when you're doing frame development with JavaScript. ###### Script Tag Soup ###### We started out years ago and had tag soup where we had lots and lots of script tags. They all had to be kept in the right order. It was really hard to debug if a dependency was loaded out of order. ![Tag Soup](/content/images/2015/03/tag-soup.png) ###### Node.js: CommonJS module format ###### What we have in this module format is a much cleaner system with basically no mental overhead and no boiler plate. > You simply say, "I need this other file with this name (./dep). > This is what I want to call the variable (dep) that its value is going to be put into." main.js 
var dep = require('./dep');

console.log(dep.foo, dep.bar);
> Then in that file you just explicitly say, "I want to expose a property named 'foo'. > I want to expose a property named 'bar'." dep.js 
exports.foo = 'foo';
exports.bar = 'bar';
Or alternatively you could just expose a single function. dep.js 
module.exports = function () {
  // do stuff
}
It's extremely straightforward, what your module is exposing and what your module is getting back, how it's being assigned. Terminal ```bash $ node main.js foo bar ``` ###### CommonJS Basics Introduction ###### In the CommonJS module format, the way that you expose a value to other files that want to reference your file is by using the **module.exports** object. We could expose a function here that we'll just have it return the same string. dep.js 
module.exports = function () {
  return "I am a dependency";
}
If we then go back to main.js, we are now going to be getting that function reference back in this variable. main.js 
var dep = require('./dep');

console.log(dep());
We're actually going to have to call that function if we want to get the same output. Terminal ```bash $ node main.js foo bar ``` This is the main way that you're going to see things exposed from CommonJS modules. Generally, it's going to be a function. In future videos, we'll look at how you can use the CommonJS module format for frontend development using a tool called **Browserify**. HomeCreating Demo API's with json-server

## $ npm init ## When you're going to work with **Node.js** or **Browserify**, the easiest way to get started and prime your working directory is to use the **npm init** command. If we type "**npm init**" we're going to get a series of questions here. Terminal 
$ npm init
This utility will walk you through creating a package.json file.
It only covers the most common items, and tries to guess sane defaults.

See `npm help json` for definitive documentation on these fields
and exactly what they do.

Use `npm install  --save` afterwards to install a package and
save it as a dependency in the package.json file.

Press ^C at any time to quit.
name: (npm-init) 
version: (1.0.0) 
description: 
entry point: (index.js) 
test command: 
git repository: 
keywords: 
author: 
license: (ISC) 
About to write to /Users/bit/Documents/pixbit/github/edwinestrada/npm-init/package.json:

{
  "name": "npm-init",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC"
}


Is this ok? (yes)
**[12]** It asks for the name. It's going to use the directory name by default. **[13]** It asks for a version. We usually start that off at zero. **[14]** Description. You can provide a description of your module here. I usually leave it blank when I'm getting started. **[15]** The entry point -- what will be the main file used for this module once it's done. **[16]** A test command to use for running unit tests. **[17]** Git repository. If I had set this up with a Git url already, it would prepopulate that and know where my Git repository is located. **[18]** You can provide keywords to indicate the sorts of things that your package does. **[19]** You can provide an author **[20]** License ISC is basically a simplified version of MIT. If you want to change that to MIT or Apache or something, you can type in there. **[23-33]** Then you get a preview of what this file is going to look like. **[36]** You can say yes, this is OK. It is going to then generate the package JSON that you have just instructed it to use. > We've got a basic starting point **package.json** file to manage our dependencies. --- ## $ npm install ## > Now that we have our **package.json** established, we can start actually installing some dependencies that we're going to use for our project. The first thing we're going to install is '**Underscore**', so I'm just going to say, "**npm install -S underscore**". Terminal 
$ npm install -S underscore
$ cat package.json 
{
  "name": "npm-init",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "dependencies": {
    "underscore": "^1.8.2"
  }
}
**[14]** And what the '**-S**' is going to do is its going to make sure that dependency that we have just installed is now listed in this **package.json** file. What that means is that when somebody else downloads my project, they can simply run '**npm install**' without any arguments and using the **package.json dependencies** listed, and **NPM** will know exactly what to install. Now that we've run this command, you can see if we open the node modules folder here, we've got **Underscore** installed and it's right there for us. Terminal ```bash $ ls node_modules/ underscore ``` One other way to do things and sort of another tip is you can use simply '**npm i**' to install. If you use '**-D**', the dependencies are going to get installed to the dev dependencies part of your **package.json**. This time we're going to install Mocha. Terminal ```bash $ npm i -D mocha $ ls node_modules/ mocha underscore $ cat package.json { "name": "npm-init", "version": "1.0.0", "description": "", "main": "index.js", "scripts": { "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1" }, "author": "", "license": "ISC", "dependencies": { "underscore": "^1.8.2" }, "devDependencies": { "mocha": "^2.2.1" } } ``` So if we now look at this, we've got **Underscore in our dependencies** and **Mocha is in our dev dependencies**. Essentially what this does is things like test libraries - like Mocha or anything else - that are only going to be used if somebody is working on your module. If we actually go ahead and delete our node modules folder, you can pretend you are a different developer now. We have downloaded this project and just based on this the contents of this **packaged.json**, we can simply run '**npm i**'. Terminal ```bash $ rm -rf node_modules/ $ npm i npm WARN package.json npm-init@1.0.0 No description npm WARN package.json npm-init@1.0.0 No repository field. npm WARN package.json npm-init@1.0.0 No README data underscore@1.8.2 node_modules/underscore mocha@2.2.1 node_modules/mocha escape-string-regexp@1.0.2 supports-color@1.2.1 diff@1.0.8 growl@1.8.1 commander@2.3.0 mkdirp@0.5.0 (minimist@0.0.8) jade@0.26.3 (mkdirp@0.3.0, commander@0.6.1) debug@2.0.0 (ms@0.6.2) glob@3.2.3 (inherits@2.0.1, graceful-fs@2.0.3, minimatch@0.2.14) ``` npm is going to look at that **packaged.json** file, see that we depend both on **Underscore** and **Mocha** and then go and install both of those dependencies into our **node_modules** folder. Terminal ```bash $ ls node_modules/ mocha underscore ``` --- ## CLI node modules ## Some node modules provide a **command line utility** that can be used from the **shell**. Mocha is one of the things that does that. The way that it does that is in Mocha's **package.json** it lists, in this case, two files. Generally there's just going to be one. In this .bin identifier it lists out the files that it would like for MPM to make available from the command line. ![](/content/images/2015/03/npm-mocha-bin.png) What **NPM** does in response is it creates this .bin folder within your node modules folder. It's regularly hidden from view. Terminal ```bash $ ls node_modules/mocha/bin/ _mocha mocha ``` It then creates shortcuts to those files that were specified by Mocha. What you can then do to run that directly from the shell is to simply use that path to the local node modules folder and then .bin and then the name of the file. Terminal ```bash $ ./node_modules/.bin/mocha --version 2.2.1 ``` In this case we're just going to ask for the version. You can see there that the locally installed version of Mocha is 2.2.1. > Now, a lot of tutorials and instructions that you'll see recommend to install things globally simply so that you can run them from the command line but that's actually entirely unnecessary. 1. You can use the method that we just did to access the local path. - You can use the scripts fields of your package.json which we'll cover later - Or the even easier way is to simply add that local path that we just used to your path environment variable But if you were to add the ./node_modules./bin to your local path you can then simply use this file directly. I can just say **mocha --version** and it's going to be that locally installed version. Terminal ```bash $ export PATH="$PATH:./node_modules/.bin" $ mocha --version 2.2.1 ``` I can even say **which mocha** and it will tell me that I'm point at that locally installed version. Terminal ```bash $ which mocha ./node_modules/.bin/mocha ``` ## Configuring npm package.json scripts ## When **npm** initialized our **package.json** file for us it created a '**scripts**' field and within it entered a test entry which right now is just going to echo out an error message. Terminal ```bash $ cat package.json { "name": "npm-init", "version": "1.0.0", "description": "", "main": "index.js", "scripts": { "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1" }, "author": "", "license": "ISC", "dependencies": { "underscore": "^1.8.2" }, "devDependencies": { "mocha": "^2.2.1" } } ``` The scripts field is extremely useful and a recommended way for you to provide workflow scripts for your module and for people that are using it. Right now, if we were just to say, **npm test**, it's going to spit out that error message that we see defined here. Terminal ```bash $ npm test > npm-init@1.0.0 test /Users/bit/Documents/pixbit/github/edwinestrada/npm-init > echo "Error: no test specified" && exit 1 Error: no test specified npm ERR! Test failed. See above for more details. npm ERR! not ok code 0 ``` But making sure that your module's test can be run with **npm test** is a big part of being a good module author. ###### Setting up $npm test ###### To demonstrate this, I've just defined the functionality of our module to just be a simple function that will convert a string to upper case. Terminal ```bash $ vim index.js ``` index.js 
module.exports = function (str) {
    return str.toUpperCase();
}
I've written a simple mocha test: Terminal ```bash $ npm i -D chai $ vim test.js ``` test.js 
var up = require('./'),
    expect = require('chai').expect;

describe('my file', function () {
    it('should convert strings to upper case', function () {
        expect(up('hello')).to.equal('HELLO');
    });
});
**[1]** requires the file. This '**./**' just means that it's going to look in the current directory and default to a file named "index". **[6]** We just have a simple test here that just says expect **up("hello")** to equal **HELLO in uppercase**. If we just run '**mocha test.js**', we can see that that does work. Terminal ```bash $ node_modules/.bin/mocha test.js my file should convert strings to upper case 1 passing (7ms) ``` We can see our test is passing! But in order for somebody using your module to know that you're using Mocha, that the file is called **test.js**, that's a little bit more work than they should really have to do. What it's better to do, is to go in here and update this test field with that exact command. If we put that into our test field we can then come down here and say, **npm test**, and it's going to run that exact command for us so we can see that our tests are passing. Terminal ```bash $ vim package.json ``` package.json 
{
  "name": "npm-init",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "node_modules/.bin/mocha test.js"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "dependencies": {
    "underscore": "^1.8.2"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "chai": "^2.1.2",
    "mocha": "^2.2.1"
  }
}
Now somebody can install your module, run **npm test**, and they don't need to know or care about what sort of testing library you're using or how things are set up. They know that your tests are passing. There's also a shortcut. You can do **npm t**. Test and a few other ones are sort of special fields in the npm world. You can run them directly like we just saw with **npm test**. You can also add custom ones here. If we wanted to add something like a check version. We'll make that run **mocha --version**. If we then save this we can then run this custom script by doing '**npm run checkversion**'. package.json 
{
  "name": "npm-init",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "node_modules/.bin/mocha test.js",
    "checkVersion": "node_modules/.bin/mocha --version"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "dependencies": {
    "underscore": "^1.8.2"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "chai": "^2.1.2",
    "mocha": "^2.2.1"
  }
}
Terminal ```bash $ npm run checkVersion > npm-init@1.0.0 checkVersion /Users/bit/Documents/pixbit/github/edwinestrada/npm-init > mocha --version 2.2.1 ``` > Any time that you run a custom script you can just do it with **npm run** and the name. It will look for that name within your scripts field.

posts.html:
In this lesson, we introduce our sample AngularJS application and discuss our objectives for this series.

We are going to learn how to build an AngularJS application from the ground up, and literally going to start with a blank JavaScript file and a completely static HTML file.

Git Repo

Eggly, where you can essentially create, read, update and delete, in other words manage, your bookmarks.

We can click and sort our bookmarks by categories.

We are going to start from scratch, and we're going to build it up piece by piece.

From Scratch
  1. After building the static html, the first thing we're going to do is bootstrap AngularJS
  2. then we're going to focus on the views and the controllers
  3. and add in the functionality.
  4. From there we're going to start to look at sub-modules and services, and how to put those together so that your application can scale.
  5. We're going to look at how to handle complex state management using UI-router
  6. and from there we're going to get into some fun things, like animations and directives
  7. and then even testing.

The sky is the limit.

But for the first part of this, we are going to focus on getting started with AngularJS, and how to add in functionality using views and controllers.

Video SeriesBootstrapping

posts.markdown: > In this lesson, we learn how to take a static HTML page and tap into the power of AngularJS by bootstrapping the framework. ![Part 1: Getting Started](/content/images/2015/03/egghead-angular-build-an-app-tutorial-lesson.png) > In this video I'm going to show you how to take a static HTML page and bootstrap it into a working AngularJS application ###### AngularJS ###### The first thing that we need to do to get AngularJS working in the page is to add in the AngularJS JavaScript file. Terminal ```bash $ bower i -S angular foundation lodash ``` From there, we will hop into the code into the code. ###### Include Files ###### > git@github.com:eggheadio/egghead-angularjs-from-scratch-getting-started.git Terminal ```bash $ mkdir building-an-angular-app $ cd building-an-angular-app $ git init $ git remote add origin git@github.com:eggheadio/egghead-angularjs-from-scratch-getting-started.git $ git fetch --all $ git checkout origin master $ ls README.md app assets data index.complete.html index.finish.html index.start.html vendor $ vim index.start.html ``` I'm going to duplicate this last **script** tag here and then paste in the reference to the AngularJS JavaScript file. ![Adding Angular](/content/images/2015/03/Adding_Angular-1.png) What we have here is: - jQuery - bootstrap or foundation - lo-dash, which we're going to use for some collection manipulation and for the videos - **minified version of AngularJS** ###### ng-init ###### To get started, for the sake of illustration I am going to initialize a variable using **ng-init**. 1. I'm going to say, **ng-init="hello='world'"**. - From here, I'm going to create a big **H1** tag. - Using double curly brace syntax, I'm going to put **{{hello}}** in there. ![Hello World](/content/images/2015/03/hello_world.png) And so, when I refresh the page, and this to prove or to **show that AngularJS is not working**, and then we will hook it up so it is working. Refresh and then you get this big **{{hello}}**. Nothing is happening at the moment. ![not working](/content/images/2015/03/not_working.png) To actually get this to render, we will go up to the HTML tag and we will add in the **ng-app** attribute. How this works is: 1. when the page loads - the AngularJS JavaScript file is loaded and scans the DOM - looks for **ng-app** attribute on any of the elements - initializes an AngularJS application to that element and its children ![ng-app in html tag](/content/images/2015/03/ng-app.png) In this case, the app is initialized into the HTML tag and everything underneath it. Let's go back and refresh the page. You can see now that **{{hello}}** is being evaluated to **World**. ![working AngularJS app](/content/images/2015/03/working.png) Now we have a working AngularJS application. ###### Input Field ###### Let's go ahead and add in an input field with **type="text"**, and we're going to bind this to the **hello** object with **ng-model="hello"**. ![ng-model](/content/images/2015/03/ng-model.png) Refresh the page and from here, and when I actually start typing because the AngularJS application has been initialized when I change it in one place, it changes it in the other place. This is the beauty and the power of AngularJS is that you're now basically **extracting the model out from the DOM**. ![extract model from DOM](/content/images/2015/03/extract_model_from_DOM.png) We're going to elaborate on this concept in the next video where I introduce a **controller** into the application. We will actually hook up categories and bookmarks and make those dynamic. ![Fail Break Dancing](/content/images/2015/03/fail-break-dancing.gif) ---- Eggly IntroControllers

In this lesson, we learn how to take a static HTML page and tap into the power of AngularJS by bootstrapping the framework.

In this video I'm going to show you how to take a static HTML page and bootstrap it into a working AngularJS application

AngularJS

The first thing that we need to do to get AngularJS working in the page is to add in the AngularJS JavaScript file.

Terminal 

$ bower i -S angular foundation lodash

From there, we will hop into the code into the code.

Include Files

git@github.com:eggheadio/egghead-angularjs-from-scratch-getting-started.git

Terminal 

$ mkdir building-an-angular-app
$ cd building-an-angular-app
$ git init
$ git remote add origin git@github.com:eggheadio/egghead-angularjs-from-scratch-getting-started.git
$ git fetch --all
$ git checkout origin master
$ ls
    README.md           app                     assets
    data                index.complete.html     index.finish.html
    index.start.html    vendor
$ vim index.start.html

I'm going to duplicate this last script tag here and then paste in the reference to the AngularJS JavaScript file.

What we have here is:

  • jQuery
  • bootstrap or foundation
  • lo-dash, which we're going to use for some collection manipulation and for the videos
  • minified version of AngularJS
ng-init

To get started, for the sake of illustration I am going to initialize a variable using ng-init.

  1. I'm going to say, ng-init="hello='world'".
  2. From here, I'm going to create a big H1 tag.
  3. Using double curly brace syntax, I'm going to put {{hello}} in there.

And so, when I refresh the page, and this to prove or to show that AngularJS is not working, and then we will hook it up so it is working. Refresh and then you get this big {{hello}}. Nothing is happening at the moment.

To actually get this to render, we will go up to the HTML tag and we will add in the ng-app attribute.

How this works is:

  1. when the page loads
  2. the AngularJS JavaScript file is loaded and scans the DOM
  3. looks for ng-app attribute on any of the elements
  4. initializes an AngularJS application to that element and its children

In this case, the app is initialized into the HTML tag and everything underneath it.

Let's go back and refresh the page. You can see now that {{hello}} is being evaluated to World.

Now we have a working AngularJS application.

Input Field

Let's go ahead and add in an input field with type="text", and we're going to bind this to the hello object with ng-model="hello".

Refresh the page and from here, and when I actually start typing because the AngularJS application has been initialized when I change it in one place, it changes it in the other place.

This is the beauty and the power of AngularJS is that you're now basically extracting the model out from the DOM.

We're going to elaborate on this concept in the next video where I introduce a controller into the application.

We will actually hook up categories and bookmarks and make those dynamic.

Eggly IntroControllers

posts.title: Building an Angular App: Controllers
posts.markdown:
> We are going to take the static HTML elements and dynamically display them on the page by setting up an AngularJS controller and hooking it up with AngularJS templating in the view. ![Part 1: Getting Started](/content/images/2015/03/egghead-angular-build-an-app-tutorial-lesson.png) We're to take these category elements and these bookmark elements and **define them in the controller**. Then using ng-repeat and AngularJS templating, **render them back out in the view**. ![categories and bookmarks](/content/images/2015/03/categories_and_bookmarks.png) - **create an AngularJS module** - **hook up an AngularJS controller** - **render data structures that you define in your controller** ###### ng-app directive ###### The first thing that we need to do is actually define the module that we are going to organize our code into. > An AngularJS module is simply an organizational mechanism to group functionality. > It's a way for, for instance, if you have users then you might group the user functionality into a user submodule. If you have, for instance, a bookmarks functionality or a set of bookmarks functionality you can organize that into a bookmarks submodule. You'll see this actually in later videos when we start to get into more advanced topics. For now, I'm going to go to the **ng-app** directive and I'm just going to add a value to this attribute and I'm going to say, **ng-app="Eggly"**. When this instantiates, it's going to look for a module called "**Eggly**". ![ng-app Eggly](/content/images/2015/03/ng-app_Eggly.png) ###### Reference Source File of App ###### We need to define this module, but the first thing that we need to do is actually **reference our source file for our application**. Add a script tag with source pointing to: **app/eggly-app.start.js**. ![reference source file of application](/content/images/2015/03/reference_source_file_of_application.png) Let's hop over to here. ###### Defining Module ###### eggly-app.start.js 
angular.module('Eggly', [])
.controller('MainController', function($scope){
	$scope.hello = 'world';
})
**[1]** You define your Angular module using **angular.module**. This takes two arguments, the **name of the module, "Eggly"** and then an **array of dependencies**. In this case, we do not have any dependencies yet but you could put any submodule in there. For instance, if you're doing routing or animating then you would put **ngRouter** or **ngAnimate**. **[2]** We are going to **define our controller** called **"Main Controller"**. This takes a second parameter: - either **an array with submodules or dependencies**, and then the last element of that array being the actual functionality for the controller in the form of a function - or it can just take a function. I prefer to use the function and then actually define my dependencies using **ngMin** or in a post-production step. In this case, we're just going to pass in **$scope**. **[3]** Just to show that this is working let's create a variable called **$scope.hello** and we're going to instantiate this to **'world'**. Let's hop back in here. We have to actually define the controller in our HTML. We're going to use **ng-controller**. We're going to set this to **"MainController"**. ![ng-controller](/content/images/2015/03/ng-controller.png) > Now this controller controls the element that it was defined on and all of its subelements or children elements. From here I'm just going to go set an **h1** tag to **{{hello}}**, and let's refresh the page which should evaluate to "**world**". ![h1-hello](/content/images/2015/03/h1-hello.png) ![evaluate to world](/content/images/2015/03/evaluate_to_world.png) Now our controller is hooked up. It's live. ###### Categories and Bookmarks ###### Let's delete this. What I'm going to do now is I am going to define a categories and bookmarks array in this controller. I'm not actually going to type this out. I'm just going to paste this in here. ![categories and bookmarks in controller](/content/images/2015/03/categories_and_bookmarks_in_controller.png) **[5-10]** What I have is scope.categories. It's an array with objects for categories with an ID and a name. **[12-22]** Then, bookmarks is also an array of objects with ID, title, URL, and category. You can see that the category actually matches up to the category that it's in. Now that I've defined categories and bookmarks on scope, it's now available in the view for binding. Let's go ahead and do that. We want to actually repeat this list item element. We're going to go here. Using **ng-repeat**, we're going to say, **ng-repeat="category in categories"**. ![ng-repeat category in categories](/content/images/2015/03/ng-repeat_category.png) **[20]** What this does is it looks for the categories array and then it will basically stamp out this element once per element or item in the collection. **[21]** From here, we simply can do the double curly braces and category. That's a variable that keeps track of the current category that it's referencing in the categories array. Let's put **{{category.name}}**. Let's hop into the HTML, refresh. Now you can see that we have these four categories here. - development - design - exercise - humor ![categories](/content/images/2015/03/ng-repeat.png) Let's do the same thing for the bookmarks. ![bookmarks](/content/images/2015/03/bookmarks.png) **[26]** We want to repeat the first bookmark. Let's do **ng-repeat="bookmark in bookmarks"** like so. **[29]** Let's change this **href="{{bookmark.url}}"** and let's change the contents to **{{bookmark.title}}**. When we refresh this now, we should have categories that are dynamic and we have the bookmarks that are also rendering dynamically as they are being pulled from the controller. ![categories rendered dynamically](/content/images/2015/03/categories_rendered_dynamically.png) ###### Summary ###### Just to review what we've done, we've taken **ng-app** and now we are pointing it to the **Eggly** submodule which we defined, **angular.module('Eggly',**)..., and then on top of that module we have defined a "**MainController**" with two arrays of objects, **category** and **bookmarks**. Because we have put that on scope that is available for the view. > Think of scope as the glue between the controller and the view. Then using the **ng-repeat** syntax we are repeating over categories and bookmarks and, in this case, **category and categories** as we can now reference that object and bind to it. Now we're binding into displaying the category name. Then down here we are binding to the URL and the bookmark title. ###### One Step Further ###### In the next video, I'm going to show you how, when you actually click on a category, we can actually filter out and show just the bookmarks for that category. We've seen how to actually bind two properties in the controller but now we're going to take it one step further and we're going to actually show how to add in functionality or communicate back to the controller from the view. ![Deal with it](/content/images/2015/03/deal-with-it-driving.gif) --- BootstrappingFilters

We are going to take the static HTML elements and dynamically display them on the page by setting up an AngularJS controller and hooking it up with AngularJS templating in the view.

We're to take these category elements and these bookmark elements and define them in the controller.

Then using ng-repeat and AngularJS templating, render them back out in the view.

  • create an AngularJS module
  • hook up an AngularJS controller
  • render data structures that you define in your controller
ng-app directive

The first thing that we need to do is actually define the module that we are going to organize our code into.

An AngularJS module is simply an organizational mechanism to group functionality.

It's a way for, for instance, if you have users then you might group the user functionality into a user submodule.

If you have, for instance, a bookmarks functionality or a set of bookmarks functionality you can organize that into a bookmarks submodule. You'll see this actually in later videos when we start to get into more advanced topics.

For now, I'm going to go to the ng-app directive and I'm just going to add a value to this attribute and I'm going to say, ng-app="Eggly".

When this instantiates, it's going to look for a module called "Eggly".

Reference Source File of App

We need to define this module, but the first thing that we need to do is actually reference our source file for our application.

Add a script tag with source pointing to: app/eggly-app.start.js.

Let's hop over to here.

Defining Module

eggly-app.start.js 

angular.module('Eggly', [])  
.controller('MainController', function($scope){
    $scope.hello = 'world';
})

[1] You define your Angular module using angular.module. This takes two arguments, the name of the module, "Eggly" and then an array of dependencies. In this case, we do not have any dependencies yet but you could put any submodule in there. For instance, if you're doing routing or animating then you would put ngRouter or ngAnimate.

[2] We are going to define our controller called "Main Controller". This takes a second parameter:

  • either an array with submodules or dependencies, and then the last element of that array being the actual functionality for the controller in the form of a function
  • or it can just take a function. I prefer to use the function and then actually define my dependencies using ngMin or in a post-production step. In this case, we're just going to pass in $scope.

[3] Just to show that this is working let's create a variable called $scope.hello and we're going to instantiate this to 'world'.

Let's hop back in here. We have to actually define the controller in our HTML. We're going to use ng-controller. We're going to set this to "MainController".

Now this controller controls the element that it was defined on and all of its subelements or children elements.

From here I'm just going to go set an h1 tag to {{hello}}, and let's refresh the page which should evaluate to "world".

Now our controller is hooked up. It's live.

Categories and Bookmarks

Let's delete this. What I'm going to do now is I am going to define a categories and bookmarks array in this controller.

I'm not actually going to type this out. I'm just going to paste this in here.

[5-10] What I have is scope.categories. It's an array with objects for categories with an ID and a name.

[12-22] Then, bookmarks is also an array of objects with ID, title, URL, and category. You can see that the category actually matches up to the category that it's in.

Now that I've defined categories and bookmarks on scope, it's now available in the view for binding. Let's go ahead and do that.

We want to actually repeat this list item element. We're going to go here. Using ng-repeat, we're going to say, ng-repeat="category in categories".

[20] What this does is it looks for the categories array and then it will basically stamp out this element once per element or item in the collection.

[21] From here, we simply can do the double curly braces and category. That's a variable that keeps track of the current category that it's referencing in the categories array. Let's put {{category.name}}.

Let's hop into the HTML, refresh. Now you can see that we have these four categories here.

  • development
  • design
  • exercise
  • humor

Let's do the same thing for the bookmarks.

[26] We want to repeat the first bookmark. Let's do ng-repeat="bookmark in bookmarks" like so.

[29] Let's change this href="{{bookmark.url}}" and let's change the contents to {{bookmark.title}}.

When we refresh this now, we should have categories that are dynamic and we have the bookmarks that are also rendering dynamically as they are being pulled from the controller.

Summary

Just to review what we've done, we've taken ng-app and now we are pointing it to the Eggly submodule which we defined, angular.module('Eggly',)..., and then on top of that module we have defined a "MainController" with two arrays of objects, category and bookmarks.

Because we have put that on scope that is available for the view.

Think of scope as the glue between the controller and the view.

Then using the ng-repeat syntax we are repeating over categories and bookmarks and, in this case, category and categories as we can now reference that object and bind to it.

Now we're binding into displaying the category name. Then down here we are binding to the URL and the bookmark title.

One Step Further

In the next video, I'm going to show you how, when you actually click on a category, we can actually filter out and show just the bookmarks for that category.

We've seen how to actually bind two properties in the controller but now we're going to take it one step further and we're going to actually show how to add in functionality or communicate back to the controller from the view.
