  </li>
</ul>

<hr>

<!-- CREATING -->  
<ui-view ng-if="shouldShowCreating()">  
  <a href="#" ng-click="startCreating();"><i class="fa fa-plus"></i> Create Bookmark</a>
</ui-view>

We will just paste this into the bookmarks-create template, and delete this ng-show from the form tag, because we want this form to show at all times when we're in a create state.

bookmarks-create.tmpl.html 

  <form class="create-form" role="form" ng-submit="createBookmark(newBookmark)" novalidate>
      <div class="form-group">
        <label for="newBookmarkTitle">Bookmark Title</label>
        <input type="text" class="form-control" id="newBookmarkTitle" ng-model="newBookmark.title" placeholder="Enter title">
      </div>
      <div class="form-group">
        <label for="newBookmarkURL">Bookmark URL</label>
        <input type="text" class="form-control" id="newBookmarkURL" ng-model="newBookmark.url" placeholder="Enter URL">
      </div>
      <button type="submit" class="btn btn-info btn-lg">Create</button>
      <button type="button" class="btn btn-default btn-lg pull-right" ng-click="cancelCreating()">Cancel</button>
    </form>
Refactoring boomark-create controller

Now that we have the template refactored into the smaller, more specific templates, let's go into the bookmark-create module and define the create state.

bookmarks-create.js 

angular.module('categories.bookmarks.create', [

])
.config(function($stateProvider){
  $stateProvider
    .state('eggly.categories.bookmarks.create', {
      url: '/bookmarks/create',
      templateUrl: 'app/categories/bookmarks/create/bookmark-create.tmpl.html',
      controller: 'CreateBookmarkController as createBookmarkController'
    })
  ;
})
.controller('CreateBookmarkController', function(){

})
;

[4] We are going to define a config block, inject stateProvider in.

[6] We will define our first state as eggly.categories.bookmarks.create.

[7] We'll give this a URL of bookmarks/create.

[8] The template URL is going to be 'app/categories/bookmarks/create/bookmark-create.tmpl.html'

[9] The controller will be 'CreateBookmarkCtrl as createBookmarkController'.

[13] Let's go ahead and stub out this controller.

Refactoring boomark-edit controller

Let's go ahead and do the same thing for the bookmarks-edit state.

We'll hop into the bookmark-edit sub-module.

bookmark-edit.js 

angular.module('categories.bookmarks.edit', [

])
.config(function($stateProvider){
  $stateProvider
    .state('eggly.categories.bookmarks.edit', {
      url: '/bookmarks/:bookmarkID/edit',
      templateUrl: 'app/categories/bookmarks/edit/bookmark-edit.tmpl.html',
      controller: 'EditBookmarkController as editBookmarkController'
    })
  ;
})
.controller('EditBookmarkController', function(){

})
;

[4] We will define our config block, inject stateProvider in.

[6] The state will be eggly.categories.bookmarks.edit.

[7] The URL will be bookmarks. We do need to pass in a bookmarkID since this is dependent on the bookmark that we're editing.

[8] We'll do the templateUrl as 'app/categories/bookmarks/edit/bookmark-edit.tmpl.html'

[9] We will define the controller as "EditBookmarkCtrl as editBookmarkCtrl".

[13] We will just go ahead and build out this controller just real quick.

Refactoring Categories Model to handle current category

We have successfully defined the two states for creating and editing a bookmark. We need to do a few additional steps so that we can successfully navigate to these newly created states.

We are going to hop into the CategoriesModel, create a few new methods, and add an additional property to keep track of the current category we are on.

categories-model.js 

angular.module('eggly.models.categories', [

])
.service('CategoriesModel', function ($http, $q) {
  var model = this,
      URLS = {
        FETCH: 'data/categories.json'
      },
      categories,
      currentCategory;

  function extract(result){
    return result.data;
  }

  function cacheCategories(result){
    categories = extract(result);
    return categories;
  }

  model.getCategories = function () {
    return (categories) ? $q.when(categories) : $http.get(URLS.FETCH).then(cacheCategories);
  };

  /**
   * Setter for current category
   * @param {string} categoryName [name of category being set]
   */
  model.setCurrentCategory = function (categoryName){
    return model.getCategoryByName(categoryName) // promise that this category exists
      .then(function(category){
        currentCategory = category;
      })
    ;
  };

  /**
   * Getter for current category
   */
  model.getCurrentCategory = function(){
    return currentCategory;
  }

  /**
   * Getter that is specifically getting category name
   */
  model.getCurrentCategoryName = function(){
    return currentCategory ? currentCategory.name : '';
  }

  /**
   * Here is where we can manually resolve or reject a promise
   */
  model.getCategoryByName = function(categoryName) {
    var deferred = $q.defer(); // create deferred object aka put on hold

    function findCategory() {
      return _.find(categories, function(c){
        return c.name == categoryName;
      })
    }

    if(categories){
      deferred.resolve(findCategory());
    } else {
      model.getCategories()
        .then(function(result){
          deferred.resolve(findCategory());
        })
    }

    return deferred.promise; // return result of the promise on the deferred object
  }
})
;

[10] Let's define a new property called "currentCategory".

[29] We will create a method called "setCurrentCategory", that accepts a categoryName.

[30] From here, we will return the result of getCategoryByName, pass in the categoryName.

[31-33] We'll take the promised category/result that is returned from this. We'll set it to currentCategory.

[40-42] Then, let's define two more methods, which are fairly simple in nature, getCurrentCategory, which just returns currentCategory

[47-49] Define the method getCurrentCategoryName. It checks to see if currentCategory exists. If it does, it returns currentCategory.name. If not, it just returns an empty string.

Refactoring Bookmarks List Controller to handle current category

bookmarks.js 

angular.module('categories.bookmarks', [  
  'categories.bookmarks.create',
  'categories.bookmarks.edit',
  'eggly.models.categories',
  'eggly.models.bookmarks'
])
.config(function ($stateProvider) {
  $stateProvider
    .state('eggly.categories.bookmarks', {
      url: 'categories/:category',
      views: {
        'bookmarks@': {
          templateUrl: 'app/categories/bookmarks/bookmarks.tmpl.html',
          controller: 'BookmarksListController as bookmarksListController'
        }
      }
    })
})
.controller('BookmarksListController', function ($stateParams, BookmarksModel, CategoriesModel) {
  var bookmarksListController = this;

  CategoriesModel.setCurrentCategory($stateParams.category);

  BookmarksModel.getBookmarks() // returns a promise
    .then(function (bookmarks){
      bookmarksListController.bookmarks = bookmarks;
    })
  ;

  bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategory = CategoriesModel.getCurrentCategory;
  bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategoryName = CategoriesModel.getCurrentCategoryName;
})
;

[19] Now that we have modified the CategoriesModel, now that we have defined the CategoriesModel, let's inject it into the bookmarksListCtrl.

[22] Instead of setting this locally, we will pass this into or we will delegate this to the CategoriesModel and pass in the $stateParams.category property.

[25-27] From here, while I'm looking at this, let's just update result to bookmarks so that it's a little bit more self-descriptive.

[30-31] Then, we're going to pull some methods off of the CategoriesModel and make them available to the local bookmarksListCtrl. One of them is getCurrentCategory. We'll do the same for getCurrentCategoryName.

Refactor the bookmarks template

With that in place, we are ready to actually wire up this template.

bookmarks.tmpl.html 

<h1>{{bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategoryName()}}</h1>  
<ul class="bookmarks-list">  
  <li ng-class="{active: isSelectedBookmark(bookmark.id)}" ng-repeat="bookmark in bookmarksListController.bookmarks | filter: {category: bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategoryName()}">
    <a href="#" ui-sref="eggly.categories.bookmarks.edit({bookmarkID:bookmark.id})"><i class="fa fa-pencil"></i></a>
    <a href="{{bookmark.url}}" target="_blank">{{bookmark.title}}</a>
    <a href="#"><i class="fa fa-times"></i></a>
  </li>
</ul>

<hr>

<!-- CREATING -->  
<ui-view ng-if="bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategory()">  
  <a href="#" ui-sref="eggly.categories.bookmarks.create"><i class="fa fa-plus"></i> Create Bookmark</a>
</ui-view>

The first thing we need to do is update this ng-if of the ui-view element to target the bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategory(). If a current category exists, then, we will show this.

The ng-click here to initiate the creation of a bookmark is no longer valid. We're going to replace this with a ui-sref. We're going to navigate to eggly.categories.bookmarks.create.

Let's also update the ng-click event for going into the edit state. We will replace the ng-click with a ui-sref. We're going to navigate to eggly.categories.bookmarks.edit, and we're going to pass in an object with bookmarkID:bookmark.id.

Let's go ahead and update this filter in the li element's ng-repeat here to call bookmarksListController.getCurrentCategoryName().

Refactor the categories template

Let's go into the categories template.

I want to actually allow a click on the logo to reset or go back to the default category state. We'll delete that ng-click. ui-sref. We'll navigate to eggly.categories.

categories.tmpl.html 

<h1 ui-sref="eggly.categories">Eggly</h1>  
<ul class="category-list">  
  <li ng-repeat="category in categoriesListController.categories" ng-class="{'active': isCurrentCategory(category)}">
    <a ui-sref="eggly.categories.bookmarks({category:category.name})" ng-click="setCurrentCategory(category)">{{category.name}}</a>
  </li>
</ul>
Test the code

I believe I've covered everything. Let's hop into the browser, give this a spin, and see if this is working. We'll select Development, Design. You can see now we're filtering on the current category.

I can click the logo, and it goes back to the base category state.

From here, if I click "Edit", then, you can see it's navigating to the edit state.

If I click "Create", then, you can see it's navigating to the create form.

Review

We have covered quite a bit of material in this lesson, but the main thing that I'd like to just quickly go over, that we did, is we created some methods on the CategoriesModel to expose the current category that we are on.

Then we created two new routes, one to edit a current bookmark and one to create a new bookmark.

What's next

We will continue to finalize the functionality in the Eggly application.

posts.title: AngularJS Architecture: Create Bookmark
posts.html:
In this lesson, we will complete the functionality to create a bookmark.

We start by adding a createBookmark method on the BookmarksModel and then making it available to the CreateBookmarksController. From there, we flesh out the CreateBookmarksController and refactor the template to use the new "controller as" syntax.

We are going to complete the create bookmark functionality.

bookmarks-model.js 

angular.module('eggly.models.bookmarks', [

])
.service('BookmarksModel', function ($http) {
  var model = this,
      URLS = {
        FETCH: 'data/bookmarks.json'
      },
      bookmarks;

  function extract(result){
    return result.data;
  }

  function cacheBookmarks(result){
    bookmarks = extract(result);
    return bookmarks;
  }

  model.getBookmarks = function () {

posts.title: AngularJS Architecture: Edit Bookmark
posts.html:
In this lesson, we are going to complete the functionality for editing a bookmark. We will start by augmenting the BookmarksModel and then updating the controller and view to utilize the new functionality.

We will also update the BookmarksModel.getBookmarks to cache the bookmarks so that we are not overwriting our updates on every call.

In this lesson, we are going to complete the functionality for editing a bookmark in Eggly.

We're going to start with the BookmarksModel, add in the business logic, then make that available to the bookmark edit controller, and then update the template.

bookmarks-model.js 

angular.module('eggly.models.bookmarks', [

])
.service('BookmarksModel', function ($http, $q) {
  var model = this,
      URLS = {
        FETCH: 'data/bookmarks.json'
      },
      bookmarks;

  function extract(result){
    return result.data;
  }

  function cacheBookmarks(result){
    bookmarks = extract(result);
    return bookmarks;
  }

  function findBookmark(bookmarkID){
    return _.find(bookmarks, function(bookmark){
      return bookmark.id = parseInt(bookmarkID, 10);
    });
  }

  model.getBookmarkByID = function(bookmarkID){
    var deferred = $q.defer();

    if(bookmarks){
      deferred.resolve(findBookmark(bookmarkID));
    } else {
      model.getBookmarks().then(function(){
        deferred.resolve(findBookmark(bookmarkID));
      });
    }

    return deferred.promise;
  };

  model.getBookmarks = function () {
    var deferred = $q.defer();

    if(bookmarks){
      deferred.resolve(bookmarks);
    } else {
      $http.get(URLS.FETCH).then(function(bookmarks){
        deferred.resolve(cacheBookmarks(bookmarks));
      });
    }

    return deferred.promise;
  };

  model.createBookmark = function(bookmark){
    bookmark.id = bookmarks.length; // Not good for production
    bookmarks.push(bookmark);
  };

  model.updateBookmark = function(bookmark){
    var index = _.findIndex(bookmarks, function(b){ // Not good for production
      return b.id  bookmark.id;
    });

    bookmarks[index] = bookmark;
  };
})
;

[4] We'll inject the $q service into the BookmarksModel.

[20] The first thing that we're going to do is create a 'convenience function' called "findBookmark" that accepts a bookmarkID.

[21] We are going to return the results of a lodash's find method call.

[22] We are going to compare the bookmark.id in the iterator to the bookmarkID that we're passing in as a parameter. If it matches, then it will return that bookmark object.

[26-38] Then what we're going to do is make this available by creating a method called "getBookmarkByID" that takes a bookmarkID parameter and then returns the appropriate bookmark as it is called from the controller.

[27,37] Before we get started, we're actually going to resolve this with a promise.

[27] From here, we're going to create a deferred object.

[37] I like to go ahead and just finish the return statement right when I start it, because the pattern's always the same, by returning the deferred.promise object. This then frees me up to just figure out how I'm going to resolve it in between these two lines.

[29] From here, we're going to say, "If bookmarks exist",

[30] Then this is fairly easy. We just have to call deferred.resolve findBookmark and then pass in the bookmarkID.

[31] If the bookmarks do not exist, then we need to make that method call to get the bookmarks and then find the appropriate bookmark from the collection that is returned.

[32] From here, we will call model.getBookmarks.

[33] Then, in the callback method, we are going to deferred.resolve. Then we will just resolve it like we did above. This is how we can get the bookmark by ID and then make sure that we always have a bookmarks collection.

[40-52] Let's hop into the getBookmarks method. Every time we call getBookmarks, we're calling the $http service and refreshing the bookmarks collection. Now that we're editing a specific bookmark, we do not want to overwrite those changes. Let's go ahead and replace this with a call that allows us to cache this.

[44] If bookmarks exists, we're just going to resolve it with the existing bookmarks.

[46] If not, then we're just going to make the $http.get call.

[47] From here, we'll take the result/bookmarks. We will resolve it with a cached version of the bookmarks.

[54] We have the createBookmark method in place.

[59] Let's go ahead and create an updateBookmark method.

[60-62] What we're going to do here is we're just going to get the index of the bookmark that we're dealing with. Again, we're simulating a back end in memory. This is purely for example purposes. This is actually taking a single bookmark argument.

[64] Now that we have the index, we can just say, "At this index within bookmarks, go ahead and replace it with this new object". This is just for example purposes, but it will allow us to edit the bookmark object in memory.

Now that we have completed the BookmarksModel by introducing the findBookmark method, getBookmarkById. We've updated getBookmarks to actually use a cached version of the bookmarks, and then we've introduced this updateBookmark method.

Refactor bookmark-edit controller

Let's hop into the bookmark-edit controller and build this out before we update the template.

bookmark-edit.js 

angular.module('categories.bookmarks.edit', [

])
.config(function($stateProvider){
  $stateProvider
    .state('eggly.categories.bookmarks.edit', {
      url: '/bookmarks/:bookmarkID/edit',
      templateUrl: 'app/categories/bookmarks/edit/bookmark-edit.tmpl.html',
      controller: 'EditBookmarkController as editBookmarkController'
    })
  ;
})
.controller('EditBookmarkController', function($state, $stateParams, BookmarksModel){
  var editBookmarkController = this;

  function returnToBookmarks(){
    $state.go('eggly.categories.bookmarks', {
      category: $stateParams.category
    });
  }

  function cancelEditing(){
    returnToBookmarks();
  }

  function updateBookmark(bookmark){
    editBookmarkController.bookmark = angular.copy(editBookmarkController.editedBookmark);
    BookmarksModel.updateBookmark(editBookmarkController.bookmark);
    returnToBookmarks();
  }

  BookmarksModel.getBookmarkByID($stateParams.bookmarkID)
    .then(function(bookmark){
      if(bookmark) {
        editBookmarkController.bookmark = bookmark;
        editBookmarkController.editedBookmark = angular.copy(editBookmarkController.bookmark);
      } else {
        returnToBookmarks();
      }
    })
  ;

  editBookmarkController.cancelEditing = cancelEditing;
  editBookmarkController.updateBookmark = updateBookmark;

})
;

[13] The first thing we're going to need is to inject some services. We'll go with the $state, $stateParams, and the BookmarksModel.

[14] Then we'll create a top-level reference to this just as a force of habit.

Then let us start to build out the methods that we need for this controller.

[16] The first one that we need is a method to returnToBookmarks. This is exactly like we saw in the create bookmark controller.

[17] We are going to go to eggly.categories.bookmarks.

[18] We are going to pass in a category param.

[22-24] From here, let's create a method to actually call the returnToBookmarks that is a little more descriptive, called "cancelEditing." All this does is calls returnToBookmarks. This just reads a little better in the view.

Now let us get down to the star of the show, the updateBookmark method. Now it's time for us to actually create a method to update the bookmark, but before I do that, I want to actually build out the method that we're calling to actually get the bookmark that we're editing.

[32] We'll go "BookmarksModel.getBookmarkByID". We're going to call stateParams and pass in the bookmarkID.

[33] When this resolves, we're going to take the bookmark that it is returning.

[37-39] If the bookmark does not exist, we'll just go ahead and returnToBookmarks. There's no point in going any further.

[34] If the bookmark does exist

[35] We are going to create a reference to that and call this bookmark.

[36] What I'm also going to do is I like to create a copy of that that we're actually going to be editing. If you edit an object directly in memory, there's no way to back out of it. By creating a copy, such as a property called "editedBookmark", we can make all the changes we want to editedBookmark. When we're done, we just copy it back to the bookmark reference. This is a way to make edits and have it not be so destructive.

[26] Now that we've actually gotten the bookmark and we've created this bookmark reference and this editedBookmark, then we can create a method to actually update the bookmark. We're going to create a method called "updateBookmark".

[27] From here, we are going to copy the editedBookmark back to the bookmark. Using angular.copy *again, we're going to *create a copy of that and assign it to bookmark.

[28] Then we're going to call BookmarksModel.updateBookmark and pass in the editedBookmark.bookmark.

[29] From there, we are ready to returnToBookmarks.

[43,44] Now we just need to make these methods available on our controller. We will create a method for cancelEditing and do the same for updateBookmark.

Now we have not only built out the model, but we have built out the controller.

Update the bookmark-edit view with new controller and model functionality

Let's go ahead and update the template appropriately.

bookmark-edit.tmpl.html

From here, we're displaying the editedBookmark, but let's go ahead and just show the bookmark so we can see which one we are editing.

We'll update this to point to the controller, appropriately, because we're using "controller as" syntax.

Then you can see that we're editing the editedBookmark by binding to it in ng-model, here.

posts.title: AngularJS Architecture: Delete Bookmark
posts.html:
In this lesson, we are going to complete the functionality for deleting a bookmark.

Deleting a bookmark is significantly easier than creating or editing a bookmark with the essence being a single method in the BookmarksModel that we make available to the controller and view.

We are going to complete the functionality for deleting a bookmark from Eggly.

This is going to be much simpler than when we were creating a bookmark, or specifically, editing a bookmark.

This is really going to come down to a single method call in the bookmark's model, then wiring it up in the controller, and the template.

Add a single method to bookmarks model

In the bookmark's model...

bookmarks-model.js 

angular.module('eggly.models.bookmarks', [

])
.service('BookmarksModel', function ($http, $q) {
  var model = this,
      URLS = {
        FETCH: 'data/bookmarks.json'
      },
      bookmarks;

  function extract(result){
    return result.data;
  }

  function cacheBookmarks(result){
    bookmarks = extract(result);
    return bookmarks;
  }

  function findBookmark(bookmarkID){
    return _.find(bookmarks, function(bookmark){
      return bookmark.id = parseInt(bookmarkID, 10);
    });
  }

  model.getBookmarkByID = function(bookmarkID){
    var deferred = $q.defer();

    if(bookmarks){
      deferred.resolve(findBookmark(bookmarkID));
    } else {
      model.getBookmarks().then(function(){
        deferred.resolve(findBookmark(bookmarkID));
      });
    }

    return deferred.promise;
  };

  model.getBookmarks = function () {
    var deferred = $q.defer();

    if(bookmarks){
      deferred.resolve(bookmarks);
    } else {
      $http.get(URLS.FETCH).then(function(bookmarks){
        deferred.resolve(cacheBookmarks(bookmarks));
      });
    }

    return deferred.promise;
  };

  model.createBookmark = function(bookmark){
    bookmark.id = bookmarks.length; // Not good for production
    bookmarks.push(bookmark);
  };

  model.updateBookmark = function(bookmark){
    var index = _.findIndex(bookmarks, function(b){ // Not good for production
      return b.id  bookmark.id;
    });

    bookmarks[index] = bookmark;
  };

  model.deleteBookmark = function(bookmark){
    _.remove(bookmarks, function(b){ // Not good for production
      return b.id == bookmark.id;
    });
  };
})
;

[67] we are going to create a method called "deleteBookmark", that takes a bookmark object.

[68] From here, we are going to call a low dash method called "Remove".

[69] It just iterates over the bookmarks collection, compares the ID. If there is a match, then it will remove it from the bookmarks collection. I've said this before, but I will say this again. This is merely for illustration purposes. We are simulating a backend in memory, but for these purposes, it works and we can convey the point that we are trying to get across.

posts.title: AngularJS Architecture: Animate state transitions with ui-router
posts.markdown:
> In this lesson, we are going to learn how easy it is to **animate** **ui-router state** changes using **ngAnimate** and about 10 lines of CSS. ![Eggly Series 2 Banner](/content/images/2015/03/eggly-series-2-banner.png) We are going to **animate** the **state changes** in **ui-router** using **ngAnimate**. The first thing we need to do is add in the **ngAnimate** submodule resource because it's not a part of core. Terminal ```bash $ bower install angular-animate --save ``` We'll just add the **JS resource** into our **index.html**. index.html ```php
``` ---- ###### Add ngAnimate submodule to main app file ###### Then we'll hop into our main application file here... eggly.js 
angular.module('Eggly', [
  'ngAnimate',
  'ui.router',
  'categories',
  'categories.bookmarks'
])
.config(function($stateProvider, $urlRouterProvider) {
  $stateProvider
    .state('eggly', {
      url: '',
      abstract: true
    });

  $urlRouterProvider.otherwise('/');
});
**[2]** Add in the ngAnimate submodule. --- ###### Add animations to CSS file ###### Then we will put our animations in the animations.css file. How this works is we'll define our base animation using this syntax here. animate.css ```bash [ui-view].ng-enter, [ui-view].ng-leave { position: absolute; left: 0; right: 0; -webkit-transition:all .5s ease-in-out; transition:all .5s ease-in-out; } [ui-view].ng-enter { opacity: 0; } [ui-view].ng-enter-active { opacity: 1; } [ui-view].ng-leave { opacity: 1; } [ui-view].ng-leave-active { opacity: 0; } ``` We've defined the base transition. We need to define an animation or transition from when a **ui-view** state is initiated to when it is actively applied. We'll go, "ng-enter." We'll start with opacity of zero. When this state is actively applied or essentially the **finished** state or **completed** state of this, we want **opacity to be one**. What we are going to do now is just copy this. We're going to reverse it. We'll go, "**ng-leave**". When **ng-leave** is initiated, we're going to set the property, and then, when it's actively applied, we'll set it to something else. In this case, we want it to go from **full opacity to zero opacity**. What we've done is we've defined our base transition using this "[ui-view].ng-enter, [ui-view].ng-leave". Then we've defined the enter and enter active states of opacity zero, opacity one. Then we've done the reverse for ng-leave. --- ###### Test the code in the browser ###### Let's hop into the browser and see this in action. Refresh the page. You can see that now things are starting to actually really transition in quite nicely. We were able to do that by just adding the ngAnimate code or submodule into our code and then defining these few simple states using CSS. I love the ng animations. I think it just really gives an application an one-up in terms of the user experience. They're super-easy to add. It just makes it look really nice. --- Delete BookmarkReview

</html>
Add ngAnimate submodule to main app file

Then we'll hop into our main application file here...

eggly.js 

angular.module('Eggly', [  
  'ngAnimate',
  'ui.router',
  'categories',
  'categories.bookmarks'
])
.config(function($stateProvider, $urlRouterProvider) {
  $stateProvider
    .state('eggly', {
      url: '',
      abstract: true
    });

  $urlRouterProvider.otherwise('/');
});

[2] Add in the ngAnimate submodule.

Add animations to CSS file

Then we will put our animations in the animations.css file.

How this works is we'll define our base animation using this syntax here.

animate.css 

[ui-view].ng-enter, [ui-view].ng-leave {
  position: absolute;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  -webkit-transition:all .5s ease-in-out;
  transition:all .5s ease-in-out;
}

[ui-view].ng-enter {
  opacity: 0;
}

[ui-view].ng-enter-active {
  opacity: 1;
}

[ui-view].ng-leave {
  opacity: 1;
}

[ui-view].ng-leave-active {
  opacity: 0;
}

We've defined the base transition. We need to define an animation or transition from when a ui-view state is initiated to when it is actively applied.

We'll go, "ng-enter." We'll start with opacity of zero.

When this state is actively applied or essentially the finished state or completed state of this, we want opacity to be one.

What we are going to do now is just copy this. We're going to reverse it.

We'll go, "ng-leave". When ng-leave is initiated, we're going to set the property, and then, when it's actively applied, we'll set it to something else.

In this case, we want it to go from full opacity to zero opacity.

What we've done is we've defined our base transition using this "[ui-view].ng-enter, [ui-view].ng-leave".

Then we've defined the enter and enter active states of opacity zero, opacity one.

Then we've done the reverse for ng-leave.

Test the code in the browser

Let's hop into the browser and see this in action. Refresh the page.

You can see that now things are starting to actually really transition in quite nicely.

We were able to do that by just adding the ngAnimate code or submodule into our code and then defining these few simple states using CSS.

I love the ng animations. I think it just really gives an application an one-up in terms of the user experience. They're super-easy to add. It just makes it look really nice.

posts.title: AngularJS Architecture: Review
posts.markdown: > In this lesson, we review the high level concepts that we covered over the course of this series including **file structure**, **sub-modules**, **data models**, **ui-router**, and **animations**. ![Eggly Series 2 Banner](/content/images/2015/03/eggly-series-2-banner.png) Now that we have completed the Eggly architecture series, I wanted to take a moment to review the key concepts that we covered over the course of this series. When we started the application, we had all of this layout in a single HTML page. As well as we had this large, monolithic main controller in the Eggly-app.js. Over the course of this series, we started to break that out and refactor it into meaningful and specific places and pieces of code. We created a file structure that reflected the entities that existed within the Eggly application, the main two entities being **categories** and **bookmarks**. We created a **categories** folder and within that, we put a **bookmarks** directory because we are **creating** and **editing** a bookmark. Each one of those requires a separate **controller** and **view**. We created a directory for those as well. Once we had the **file structure** in place, we started to build out **sub-modules**. We started with the **main Eggly module** and then from here we introduced the **categories module**. Then we introduced the **categories.bookmarks module** and built it all the way out to **create** and **edit**. With the **sub-modules** in place we also introduced the concept of **promoting data to models**. We took out the local data within the **main controller** and promoted it to a **bookmarks model** and a **categories model** where we talked about some different strategies for **retrieving the data**, **caching the data**, and **performing business logic**. From here, we introduced **ui-router** and started to build out states to navigate from the different states or routes in our Eggly application. We started out with a very basic, **abstract Eggly route** that is a **placeholder for all of the rest of our routes within the application**. Then we defined our **categories route** with **two named views**. Categories targeting the **categories ui-view** and the **bookmarks** named **route targeting** the **ui-view named bookmarks**. Then we also created a unique route for the state where you have actually a **category** selected to show just the **bookmarks** for that **category** in **Eggly.categories.bookmarks**. Then we created a **create** and **edit** state as well for **editing** and **creating** a bookmark. Once those were in place and we were able to navigate to the specific places within the application, we needed to go back and wire up the functionality we introduced in the first app into our new app. We set up the ability to **create** a bookmark, **edit** a bookmark, and **delete** a bookmark. Once those were completed, we finished things off with a fun animation to **animate** between **ui-router state changes**. In about 20 lines of code, we were able to add in a really nice transition and end up with a much nicer, cleaner extensible version of the Eggly application. Animate State Transitions

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Deploying to Heroku: Introduction
posts.markdown: > In this module we are going to learn all about deploying our application to Heroku. We'll look at how to set up a **MongoDB instance** that will work when our application is running in the Cloud on Heroku. After that is done we'll actually deploy our application by pushing it to Heroku with Git. Once our application is up and running, we'll discuss how to troubleshoot application issues with Heroku. There will be two sections here: - one on some general troubleshooting tips - one section devoted to troubleshooting and managing your SSH keys --- ###### Heroku ###### **Heroku** is a popular Cloud platform as a service (**PaaS**). It supports many programming languages. Of course, for our needs we only care about **Node.js**. **Heroku** is extremely popular for **Node** applications since you can get some basic hosting for free and it will scale as you do. In addition, it supports many add-ons that can provide a lot of value to your application. In order to use **Heroku** for deployments, we'll need to do two things. - First, create an account with Heroku. If you simply go to **[heroku.com](http://heroku.com)** you will be prompted here to sign up for free. - Second, you need to download and install the Heroku tool belt. That is available as a free download at **[toolbelt.heroku.com](http://toolbelt.heroku.com)**. ![Heroku Toolbelt](/content/images/2015/04/Heroku_Toolbelt.png) Once you have downloaded and installed the toolbelt, be sure to close down and reopen your command shell and the Heroku command line interface will now be available for you to use. Now let's move on and get our application deployed to Heroku. --- Walking Skeleton SummaryPreparing for Heroku

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Deploying to Heroku: Heroku and MongoDB
posts.markdown:
> In this section we're going to talk about configuring our application to work with MongoDB once it's been deployed to Heroku. As it stands right now, my application is set to write against a **local instance of MongoDB**. You can see that here in my **MongoDB connection string**. 
development: {
    db: 'mongodb://localhost/mydatabase',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 3030
  },
Unfortunately, once I push to **Heroku**, **Heroku** is not gonna have access to the **MongoDB instance running on my development machine**. Also, **Heroku** itself does not offer **MongoDB** hosting, but what **Heroku** does offer is **add-ons** that allow you to use **MongoDB** with their service, **MongoHQ** and **MongoLab**. Both **MongoHQ** and **MongoLab** offer free levels of hosting, I can sign up directly with them and just use my **connection string** in order to connect from my **Heroku** application to my **MongoHQ** or **MongoLab** database. So we'll start by connecting from our development box to one of these **Mongo** hosted solutions and then we'll be ready when our application gets pushed to **Heroku** for it to connect to the **Mongo** host. So first we'll change our development box from connecting to a local **MongoDB** to connecting to one of these hosted solutions (**MongoLab**). At that point when we deploy to **Heroku**, we'll still be able to use the hosted solution. --- ###### Setup MongoLab ###### Now I've chosen **MongoLab** for this demonstration, but there's no reason that **MongoHQ** wouldn't be just as good. I'm going to start by going to **MongoLab** and creating a new database. I've previously created an account with **MongoLab**. I'm not going to walk you through that process. At this point I see a control panel that shows me what databases that I've got. Right now I have now databases so I'm gonna create a new one. ![Create a new database](/content/images/2015/04/Pluralsight_Player.png) I can choose a bunch of different Cloud providers. I'll just leave it on **Amazon web services**. Down in the plan I'm going to click on **development**, then leave **sandbox** clicked. I'm fine with the default version of **MongoDB**. I'll get a half a gig of storage space, and now I get to name my database, which I'll call **Multivision**. And now my new database has been created. Now in order to connect to this database I'm going to need the connection information, which I'll get by clicking on the database itself, and the connection information is shown up here at the top. ![db connection information](/content/images/2015/04/database_connection.png) Here is the information I would need in order to connect using the Mongo shell, and here is the information I would need in order to use a **MongoDB** connection string. So far, I don't have any **users** in my **database** so I need to create one before I can connect to the **database**. For the database user name I'm going to type in **edwin** and for the password I'll just type in **12mm0n5t3r**, all lowercase. At this point my user's been created, so I'll scroll back up and copy the **MongoDB** connection string sample that it gives me. Now we'll go back to our code. I'm gonna duplicate this line and put in the new **connection string** and over here I'll fill in the DB user and the password. config.js 
var path = require('path');
var rootPath = path.normalize(__dirname + '/../../');

module.exports = {
  development: {
    db: 'mongodb://localhost/mydatabase',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 3030
  },
  production: {
    db: 'mongodb://edwin:12mm0n5t3r@ds061651.mongolab.com:61651/monster',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 80
  }
}
I'll comment out this first connection line and now our application will connect to our MongoLab **MongoDB** instance. Right now our application would fail because we don't have any documents in the messages collection. So let's go to our command line and create one, but I'll first bring back up that **MongoLab** page so that I can refer to that when I'm opening up the **Mongo shell**. So I'm going to type in **Mongo** and then the connection information that MongoLab has given me, then my **username**, and my **password**. And now I've connected to my **MongoDB** instance over on MongoLab. So if type in show collections, you can see that **MongoLab** has already created one system collections for me. So let's create that document in the **messages** collection so that when our application requests it, it will receive a value from our MongoLab instance. Terminal ```bash $ mongo ds061651.mongolab.com:61651/monster -u edwin -p 12mm0n5t3r > show collections system.indexes > db.messages.insert({message: 'Hello from MongoLab'}) > ^C bye $ nodemon server.js ``` Okay, now that our document has been created, we can go back and start up our application. And our application's telling us that it has indeed connected to that **database**. So let's open up our application in the browser, and you can see that we're getting the message from **MongoLab**. Now let's go back to our code and discuss a problem that we've created. Right now I'm created to my database on **MongoLab**, which will be fine when I deploy to **Heroku**, but when I'm in development, I want to connect to my local **database**, but I don't want to have to come into this file and constantly be changing that connection string back and forth when I move between development and production. Thankfully, we can easily solve this problem with **Node** environment variables. Remember, at the beginning, we created a variable up here called **env** that holds a string that represents which environment we're in. It defaults itself to **development**. So let's back to our code that connects to the **Mongo** database, and let's write some code that will choose the connection string based on the environment we're in. (typing) Now our application is set to use the first connection string if we're in development and the second if we're in **production**. config.js 
var path = require('path');
var rootPath = path.normalize(__dirname + '/../../');

module.exports = {
  development: {
    db: 'mongodb://localhost/mydatabase',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 3030
  },
  production: {
    db: 'mongodb://edwin:12mm0n5t3r@ds061651.mongolab.com:61651/monster',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 80
  }
}
Later on in this course, we'll refactor this code, but for now, this is sufficient. Now we can test this out by setting our **node environment variable** when we launch our server. So we'll go back to our command line and we'll stop our server and by default we should be in **development**, so let's start our server up again, and then we'll just go back to our application and refresh the page, and we simply get our **Hello Mongo** message. Now I'll go back to my command line, stop my server, and now I'll set my **Node environment variable** to be the value **production**. Setting this to any value but the string development will put my application into **production** mode. And now I can start up my server. If I was in a Bash shell or on OSX, I could actually shortcut this by simply setting the **node environment variable** on the same line like this: Terminal ```bash $ NODE_ENV=production nodemone server.js ``` And now I've got my server started, but it's in **production** mode. I'll go back and refresh and now I'm back to **production** mode and talking to my **MongoDB** instance over on **MongoLab**. Terminal ```bash $ NODE_ENV=development nodemone server.js ``` So let's set ourselves back into **development** mode, and our **development** environment is now set up correctly to run, but since we haven't set the **Node environment variable** on **Heroku**, when we deploy our application to **Heroku**, it's still going to be in **development** mode. We're going to need to change that. --- ###### What's Next ###### In the next section, I'll show you how to set that environment variable to production on **Heroku**. --- Preparing for HerokuPushing to Heroku

So let's back to our code that connects to the Mongo database, and let's write some code that will choose the connection string based on the environment we're in. (typing) Now our application is set to use the first connection string if we're in development and the second if we're in production.

config.js 

var path = require('path');  
var rootPath = path.normalize(__dirname + '/../../');

module.exports = {  
  development: {
    db: 'mongodb://localhost/mydatabase',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 3030
  },
  production: {
    db: 'mongodb://edwin:12mm0n5t3r@ds061651.mongolab.com:61651/monster',
    rootPath: rootPath,
    port: process.env.PORT || 80
  }
}

Later on in this course, we'll refactor this code, but for now, this is sufficient.

Now we can test this out by setting our node environment variable when we launch our server.

So we'll go back to our command line and we'll stop our server and by default we should be in development, so let's start our server up again, and then we'll just go back to our application and refresh the page, and we simply get our Hello Mongo message.

Now I'll go back to my command line, stop my server, and now I'll set my Node environment variable to be the value production. Setting this to any value but the string development will put my application into production mode.

And now I can start up my server. If I was in a Bash shell or on OSX, I could actually shortcut this by simply setting the node environment variable on the same line like this:

Terminal 

$ NODE_ENV=production nodemone server.js

And now I've got my server started, but it's in production mode. I'll go back and refresh and now I'm back to production mode and talking to my MongoDB instance over on MongoLab.

Terminal 

$ NODE_ENV=development nodemone server.js

So let's set ourselves back into development mode, and our development environment is now set up correctly to run, but since we haven't set the Node environment variable on Heroku, when we deploy our application to Heroku, it's still going to be in development mode. We're going to need to change that.

What's Next

In the next section, I'll show you how to set that environment variable to production on Heroku.

Preparing for HerokuPushing to Heroku

In the next section we'll discuss some troubleshooting tips in case you have any problems that aren't solved by simply trying to redeploy your code.

Now that my application is up on Heroku, it's still not running because I haven't told Heroku to allocate any resources to it. Heroku does this through the heroku ps:scale web=1 command, and basically this will get Heroku to allocate some resources to my application.

Terminal 

$ heroku ps:scale web=1

And you can see that Heroku is now done with that operation so my next step is simply to type in heroku open.

Terminal 

$ heroku open

This will open my current Heroku app in my browser. And our application is now up and running on Heroku.

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Designing the UI: Creating the Header and Footer
posts.markdown:
> In this section, we're going to start designing our UI by adding a header and a footer to our page. The very first thing we'll do is add a title to our application. So, I'm going to go into the head of my layout and add a title of "Monster". Next, I want to add the header to my application. Now, in a server-side rendered application, you would probably do this inside of your layout file. But since this is a **client-side, single-page application**, I'm actually going to do this in the **index** file. So, go into my **index** file and inside the **main content block**, I'm going to start by adding my **header**. index.jade 
extends common/layout

block main-content
  nav.top-bar(data-topbar='', role='navigation')
    ul.title-area
      li.name
        h1
          a(href="/") Monster
      li.toggle-topbar.menu-icon
        a(href='#')
          span Menu
    section.top-bar-section
      ul.left
        li.has-form
          div(ng-include="'/partials/navbar-login'")
      ul.right
        li.divider
        li
          a(href="/") Home

  section.content
    div(ng-view)

  footer.row
    p.small-3.small-centered.columns © 2015 Evil Corporation Ltd.
My first piece of contents of my header is going to be a link to the homepage. Next, I want to add the first to a set of navigation links. And the first link in here will also be the homepage. navbar-login.jade 
.row.collapse
  .large-4.small-4.columns
    input.form-control(placeholder="Email", ng-model="username")
  .large-4.small-4.columns
    input.form-control(type="password", placeholder="password", ng-model="password")
  .large-4.small-4.columns
    a.alert.button.expand(ng-click="signin(username,password)") Sign in
Now let's go in and add our footer. I'll go back to the index page and after my content, I'm going to add a footer. And, I want to center that text on it. And, I'll give myself a copyright and put in the name of our fictitious Evil Corporation. Okay, that header and footer are looking pretty decent. The body content's a bit off to the left of our header and footer, but we'll fix that in the next section. --- IntroductionMain Page Content

In this section, we're going to add some sample data to those two panels that we created on our index page: featured courses and new courses.

But before we can begin adding that sample data, we need to do a little bit of reorganization to our Angular code.

Here in our app file, we've got the configuration for our module and the main controller.

It's time to move that controller into its own file.

Since this is the controller for the main page, I'm going to create a new folder in my client-side application called "Main", and that folder will hold all the files that have to do with the main page of my application.

So, I'll create the main controller file.

Terminal 

$ mkdir public/app/main
$ touch public/app/main/mainController.js

Cut out off app.js and paste into mainController.js.

app.js 

angular.module('app', ['ngResource', 'ngRoute']);

angular.module('app').config(function($routeProvider, $locationProvider){  
  $locationProvider.html5Mode({
    enabled: true,
    requireBase: false
  });
  $routeProvider
    .when('/', {
      templateUrl: '/partials/main',
      controller: 'mainController'
    })
  ;

});

angular.module('app').controller('mainController', function($scope){  
  $scope.myVar = "Snaaaakkkke!";
});

mainController.js 

angular.module('app').controller('mainController', function($scope){  
  $scope.myVar = "Snaaaakkkke!";
});

script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/angular-resource/angular-resource.js")  
script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/angular-route/angular-route.js")  
script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/app.js")  
script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/main/mainController.js")

Featured courses partial

And, I want to do a little bit of filtering on that data.

posts.html:
In this module and the next one we are going to implement authentication and authorization for our MEAN application.

Let's look at the agenda for the next two modules.

Authentication is the means we use to make sure that a user is who they say they are.

Authorization is the process of restricting data and functionality to only those users who are allowed to access them.

We'll begin our foray into the world of authentication and authorization by implementing login using Passport.

Passport is a very common Node module for implementing authentication.

Passport uses various different strategies for authentication and these involve anything from using a local username and password to using your Facebook account to log in.

We will be implementing the local strategy, which uses a local username and password.

Then, we'll make sure that our passwords are secure by encrypting them using a hashing algorithm.

And finally, we'll implement authorization.

Passport won't give us much help here, but implementing authorization on top of Passport is pretty straightforward.

By the time we're done with this module, we'll be comfortable with typical authentication and authorization in a Node application.

> In this section we're going to start building our **authentication and authorization systems** by just **adding the display portion for our login to our home page**. So we'll go into our **index template (index.jade)** and we're going to **add a section to the navbar**. Right after this **unordered list**, I'm going to **add another div** and I'm going to use the **ng-include directive** and **include a new partial**. index.jade 
extends common/layout

Inside of here I'll **create a form** that'll contain the **login boxes and the login button** and that'll be a **navbar form**. navbar-login.jade

I also need to make this **type=password**, and the **ng-model=password**. **[7]** And lastly we'll **create the button** that they'll **click in order to log in**. And we'll go ahead and **create an click event handler** and we'll call a **method name signin()**, passing in the **username and password**, and that **button will have the text of "Sign In"**. Now I've already got my **server** running so let's just go and **refresh our page** and see how these new controls look. ![Sign In](/content/images/2015/04/localhost_3030-3.png) --- ###### Partials Directory Refactoring ###### One of the things that is beginning to bother me is that our **partials directory** is starting to get a little bit crowded. The problem is that these files do a lot of different things and don't really have any association other than the fact that they're **partials**, yet they're all in the same directory. > What would be nice is if the **partial files themselves were actually associated with the client code that they belonged to**. So for example, here in my **public directory**, inside of **app**, **any partial files that have to do with the main section**, it'd be nice if they were in a **main subfolder here underneath partials**. So I might put **main.jade**, **new courses**, and **featured courses** inside of a **main subdirectory**, then the **navbar login** could probably go in either a **common subdirectory** or maybe an **account subdirectory**. So let's go ahead and do that. Let's create a **main subdirectory underneath partials** and **put our three files inside that** and let's **create an account subdirectory and put our navbar login partial inside of that one**. So first I'll create that **main directory**, and then I'll move **featured courses** inside of that, and the **main file**, and the **new courses**, and I'll **create another directory called account**, and I'll put the **navbar login inside of that**. ![Main and Account Directories](/content/images/2015/04/main_jade_-__Users_edwin_Documents_github_pluralsight_building-angularjs-and-nodejs-apps-with-the-mean-stack_mean-monster_-_Atom.png) Now I've got to go through and **change some paths in order to reference these new locations**. --- So I'll go back to my **index.jade**. index.jade 
extends common/layout

block main-content
  nav.top-bar(data-topbar='', role='navigation')

      ul.right
        li.divider
        li
          a(href="/") Home

  section.content
    div(ng-view)

  footer.row
    p.small-3.small-centered.columns © 2015 Evil Corporation Ltd.
**[15]** inside of there I'm **pointing at partials navbar login and that needs to be account** --- Then also inside of my **main.jade** file. main.jade 
.row
  .large-12.columns
    .panel
      h1 {{ myVar }}
      p It has an easy to override visual style, and is appropriately subdued.

.row
  .large-6.small-6.columns
    div(ng-include="'/partials/main/featured-courses'")
  .large-6.small-6.columns
    div(ng-include="'/partials/main/new-courses'")
**[9,11]** Where I'm referencing **featured and new courses**, I'll **put main in here**. --- Then finally in my **app.js** file. app.js 
angular.module('app', ['ngResource', 'ngRoute']);

angular.module('app').config(function($routeProvider, $locationProvider){
  $locationProvider.html5Mode({
    enabled: true,
    requireBase: false
  });
  $routeProvider
    .when('/', {
      templateUrl: '/partials/main/main',
      controller: 'mainController'
    })
  ;

});
**[10]** This is where I'm **pointing at the main partial** and that changes to **/partials/main/main**. --- And now that I've got those changes made, if I **refresh the page**, we're actually going to **get an error**. > This is one of the dangers of using complex routing with your partials especially when paired with a catch all route that just returns the **index.html**. Let's go **refresh our page** and see what happens. I'm going to **open up the console** and make it just a little bit bigger before I refresh the page so you can **see the errors** that we're getting. We've actually crashed the page and it's not responding any more. Even if I click stop, the page is still working. The problem is that **my route is no longer correct**. Over here in my **server.js**, the **route to the partials only includes one subdirectory** so now that I've got **two subdirectories**, this **route isn't matching anymore**, so **all requests for partials are now getting satisfied by the star route**, which is actually just **returning the index**. That **index has a reference to a partial again**, so **Angular is getting a partial back**, which **has a reference to another ng-include**, **trying to request that partial again**, **getting another index page back** that's **got a reference to an ng-include**, and **getting into essentially an infinite loop**. Now we'll be able to fix this problem by **fixing our partial route**. So all I need to do to **fix this problem is go up to this route**. routes.js 
module.exports = function(app){
  app.get('/partials/*', function(req, res){
    res.render('common/partials/' + req.params[0]);
  });

  app.get('*', function(req, res){
    res.render('index');
  });
}
**[2]** **Change this partial path to an asterisk** **[3]** and now here in the **render column**, instead of asking for **request.params.partial path**, I want **request.params and then an indexer for the 0th element**. > **Request.params** is an array and the first element will be what matches up with the asterisk in the path. --- ###### Check in browser ###### So we'll go back to the browser. I've opened up a new tab and I've actually got to close this tab in order to get it to stop. And now we can **browse to our website**. **And if we look at the console we'll see that we're not getting any errors.** --- ###### Moving partials into app directory ###### Now that's well and good, but there's another improvement we can make. We've created this **parallel set of directories to what's up here in our app directory that contains our client-side application**, but since we're creating parallel directories, **why don't we just move these partial files up here into this directory so that they're actually alongside the files that they belong with**. I'm gonna **drag this entire account folder up here and then inside of this main folder I'm gonna grab all three of these partials and drag them up here to main, and now I can delete this partials directory**. And now **we can just change this route right here so instead of looking at partials, we'll specify a different path relative to the views directory**. We'll **go from the views directory established in express.js then into public, and then into app**. ![partials routes](/content/images/2015/04/partials_routes.png) Now any request we make **that starts with the directory partials**, we'll still **look inside of the public app directory**, but **we'll process the files as if they were Jade templates**. --- ###### Login Partial Controller ###### Our **navbar login partial is up at the top of the page**, but **it's not a child of any element that has a controller on it right now**. If we go back to our **index.jade**, we can see that here the **ng-view** is what links the **ng-controller** to this section, but our **navbar login partial** is in a different section of the page, so the **controller for the current view** won't be the **controller for the navbar login**. index.jade 
extends common/layout

block main-content
  nav.top-bar(data-topbar='', role='navigation')
    ul.title-area
      li.name
        h1
          a(href="/") Monster
      li.toggle-topbar.menu-icon
        a(href='#')
          span Menu
    section.top-bar-section
      ul.left
        li.has-form
          div(ng-include="'/partials/account/navbar-login'")
      ul.right
        li.divider
        li
          a(href="/") Home

  section.content
    div(ng-view)

  footer.row
    p.small-3.small-centered.columns © 2015 Evil Corporation Ltd.
--- ###### Giving navbar login partial it's own controller ###### I'd like it to **have its own controller** anyway so I'm going to **create a controller for this section of the page**. navbar-login.jade 
.row.collapse(ng-controller="navbarLoginController")
  .large-4.small-4.columns
    input.form-control(placeholder="Email", ng-model="username")
  .large-4.small-4.columns
    input.form-control(type="password", placeholder="password", ng-model="password")
  .large-4.small-4.columns
    a.alert.button.expand(ng-click="signin(username,password)") Sign in
**[1]** So I'll go back to my **navbar login partial** and **at the top of the page I'll specify an ng-controller** and **specify a controller for this area of the page**. --- ###### Create the controller for the navbar login partial ###### Now I need to **create that controller** and since this controller **doesn't really belong to the main area**, I'm going to **put it inside of an account subdirectory**. Terminal ```bash $ touch public/app/account/navbarLoginController.js ``` navbarLoginController.js 
angular.module('app').controller('navbarLoginController', function ($scope){
  $scope.signin = function(username, password){
    console.log("I, " + username + " am not done yet " + password);
  }
});
**[2]** Now I know that I've got a **call to a signin function** so I'll go ahead and **define that right now**. **[3]** And for now I'll just **log out a message to the console**. --- ###### Add controller to scripts tags ###### And my last step is I need to **include a script tag for this file** so I'll go to my scripts template. scripts.jade 
script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/jquery/dist/jquery.js")
script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/angular/angular.js")
script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/angular-resource/angular-resource.js")
script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/angular-route/angular-route.js")
script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/app.js")
script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/main/mainController.js")
script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/account/navbarLoginController.js")

Now that we've got our display put together and we've got our code refactored, we're ready to actually implement our login.

In this section we're going to implement a very nave login and in further sections we'll flesh it out and make it more complete.

Now for our login we're going to use Passport.

Passport is an extremely popular Node module for handling authentication.

We're going to use Passport Local, which implements authentication using a user's username and password stored locally in our own database.

As opposed to something like OAuth, which authenticates through a third party.

Now, npm install passport and passport-local.

User Schema and Model

In here I'm going to create a schema and a model for our user type.

This user type will contain not only the user's basic information like name, but also their authentication and authorization information.

posts.html:
And now we're going to implement the server-side portion of our login

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);  
require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

[3] So to do that we'll bring in the Passport module

[4] And I also need to reference to the local strategy and I get that by creating a variable called local strategy requiring Passport Local and then asking for its strategy property.

Strategies are how Passport actually implements the authentication.

As I said before, we're using a local strategy, which means that we can log in using a username and password that we keep in our own database.

There are also strategies for Twitter, Facebook, Google, and a bunch of others.

Now that we begin to add our passport code to implement the local strategy.

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);

var User = mongoose.model('User');  
passport.use(new LocalStrategy(  
  function(username, password, done){
    User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
      if(user){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  }
));

passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){  
  if(user) {
    done(null, user._id);
  }
});

passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){  
  User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
    if(user){
      return done(null, user);
    } else {
      return done(null, false);
    }
  });
});

require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

[16] We're going to tell Passport to use a local strategy that we configure.

[17] And the local strategy is implemented as a function, which takes in a username password and a done callback.

[18-24] Within here we simply implement our own code to:

  1. verify that the username and password that we're given are correct
  2. find the correct user
  3. and pass it to the done function.

[15] We'll implement Mongoose to look up a user, and in order to look up a user we've got to grab a User model.

[18] I'm going to tell the user model to find a single user so I'll call user.findOne, and it must match the username, and then when that returns it should return a single user if one is found.

So we'll make sure that the user was found and because this is a nave implementation, we won't check the password yet

[19-20] If the user was found, then I'm going to call done with a null for the error and the user as follows: done(null, user)

[21-22] If the user was not found, then I'll call done with a null and a false as follows: done(null, false).

Serializing and deserializing the users

Now there's a couple more things we have to implement to get Passport to work. We have to tell Passport how to serialize and deserialize a user.

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);

var User = mongoose.model('User');  
passport.use(new LocalStrategy(  
  function(username, password, done){
    User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
      if(user){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  }
));

passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){  
  if(user) {
    done(null, user._id);
  }
});

passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){  
  User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
    if(user){
      return done(null, user);
    } else {
      return done(null, false);
    }
  });
});

require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

[28] So to do that we will call passport.serializeUser and pass in a function that takes in a user and a done callback.

[29-31] We check that if there's actually a user and if so, we call done with null and we just wanna give it the user's ID as follows: return(null, user._id)

[34] When we import Passport's deserializeUser we'll receive in that same ID and a done function

[35] Iin there we'll look up the user matching on the ID

[37] and when that returns, we'll check that there's a user and if so return done, passing in the user as follows: done(null, user)

[39] otherwise return done, passing in false as follows: done(null, false)

Login code using XHR POST

So I go to my routes file and I want to add a new route here.

routes.js 

var passport = require('passport');

module.exports = function(app){  
  app.get('/partials/*', function(req, res){
    res.render('./' + req.params[0]);
  });

  app.post('/login', function(req, res, next){
    var auth = passport.authenticate('local', function(err, user){
      if(err) { return next(err); }
      if(!user) { return res.send({success:false}) }
      req.logIn(user, function(err){
        if(err) { return next(err); }
        res.send({
          success:true,
          user:user
        });
      });
    });
    auth(req, res, next);
  });

  app.get('*', function(req, res){
    res.render('index');
  });
}

[1] Now I'm gonna to have to bring in the Passport module

[8] And in this route will be for a post to the URL of login and this will be a little piece of middleware that will authenticate the user by grabbing the return value of calling to passport.authenticate.

[9] I tell authenticate the strategy I'm using. I can give it a callback, which takes an error and the user

[10] and check the error and just pass it along if there was one

[11] and check if there's a user, and if there's not a user then I will send to the client a JSON object that says that we failed to authenticate the user.

[9-19] This function should receive the user if the user was found using the other method via local strategy we implemented in the server.js, that calls user.findOne to look up the user by username, and if one was found, then it returns that user. It should be either the user or a false, and that's what comes through here is that user if it was found.

[12] So if neither of those two conditions were met, then we did find the user so we can actually log in the user.

We need to tell Passport to log them in and create a session for them and we do that by calling req.logIn. Login is a function that Passport adds to the request object and login takes in the user itself and a callback

[13] and then callback will also again check for errors and we'll just pass it on.

[14] Otherwise if the login was successful then we will send to the client a JSON object that specifies that we were able to successfully log in the user

[15] and also send the success property set equal to true,

[16] we'll also send the user as well.

[20] Now what's a little bit funny about Passport is calling this authenticate actually creates a function, which I've captured here in this auth variable, so now in order to make this work I actually have to call that function and pass in the request, the response, and the next

Login with a POST

Now whenever somebody hits login with a POST, it will actually execute this code.

Now we're doing things a little bit differently than are typically done with Passport because we're not logging in using a server side route, which is a submitted form.

We're actually trying to log in using an XHR POST, and normally you don't have to tell Passport to log in the user itself.

It just does that for you automatically, but since we're using XHR for our login, we actually have to tell Passport to log in the user.

Passport Middleware

Now we've got in our login code all implemented correctly for Passport, but we haven't executed the Passport middleware, so we actually need to go into our Express file for that and we need to do a couple of things in here.

express.js 

var express    = require('express'),  
  logger       = require('morgan'),
  bodyParser   = require('body-parser')
  cookieParser = require('cookie-parser'),
  session      = require('express-session'),
  passport     = require('passport');

module.exports = function(app, config){  
  app.set('views', config.rootPath + '/public/app');
  app.set('view engine', 'jade');

  app.use(logger('dev'));
  app.use(cookieParser());
  app.use(bodyParser());
  app.use(session({
    secret: 'there are monsters under my bed'
  }));
  app.use(passport.initialize());
  app.use(passport.session());

  app.use(express.static(config.rootPath + '/public'));
}

[4-5] The cookie parser and session are modules that I need to import so I'll add the import statements at the top.

[6] I need to add the Passport module to this file.

[13] We need to add in the cookie parser before the body parser since cookies are required for sessions

[15] and we also need to add in the session middleware.

[16] And for our secret I'm going to specify a string.

[18] And at this point we can tell Passport to initialize itself by calling app.use(passport.initialize()), which will initialize the Passport middleware

[19] and then we're using sessions in our implementation so I also need to tell Passport to use sessions calling app.use(passport.session())

posts.html:
Right now our login is successfully communicating with the server and logging us in on the server, but it's not really taking much effect on the client other than printing out a console message.

There's a couple of things we should do on the client:

  • We should hide the login box, so the user can't log in again as a different user without actually logging out
  • We should also store the current user and the fact that somebody's now logged in.
Notify service

So let's start out by just changing our notification.

Let's notify the user that they logged in successfully by using the Toaster library that we included previously.

So first we need to make a service that wraps around that Toaster library.

So I'm gonna go to my public folder and into my app directory, and I'm gonna create a new folder called common and inside of there I'll create a new file and I'll call it notifier.js.

Terminal 

$ mkdir public/app/common
$ touch public/app/common/notifier.js

notifier.js 

angular.module('app').value('toastr', toastr);

angular.module('app').factory('notifier', function(toastr){  
  return {
    notify: function(msg){
      toastr.success(msg);
      console.log(msg);
    }
  }
});

[1] The first thing we need to do is wrap Toaster itself inside of a service.

That'll put the Toaster global variable into a service so that we can use it in our dependency injection

[3] and then let's create a notifier service based on that.

[4-5] And my notifier is going to be an object that has a notify function that takes in a message

[6] and we'll use Toaster to show the message as follows: toaster.success(msg)

[7] and then let's also log it out to the console.

Use Notifier service in Navbar Login Controller

Alright now that we got that notifier created, we can go to our navbar login controller.

navbarLoginController.js 

angular.module('app').controller('navbarLoginController', function ($scope, $http, notifier){  
  $scope.signin = function(username, password){
    $http.post('/login', {username:username, password:password}).then(function(response){
      if(response.data.success){
        notifier.notify('You have successfully signed in!');
      }else{
        notifier.notify('Username/Password combination incorrect');
      }
    });
  }
});

[1] Inject notifer service as a dependency

[5,7] We can replace our console.log with notifier and we'll put in a nice message.

Capture the login with the Identity Service

Now let's also capture the fact that we've logged the user in.

Let's create a new service that we'll call the identity service.

So in my account folder I'll create a new file named identity.js and this service is going to:

  • store the fact that we are logged in
  • store the current user

Terminal 

$ touch public/app/account/identity.js

identity.js 

angular.module('app').factory('identity', function(){  
  return {
    currentUser: undefined,
    isAuthenticated: function(){
      return !!this.currentUser;
    }
  }
});

[2] This will just be an object that right now.

[3] That has a current user that we'll just default to undefined.

Now we could just return a blank object because when I check for current user it's going to be undefined either way, but I like the fact that we're explicitly defining that there is a current user property on this object.

[4-6] Now I'd also like to add a method to this object called isAuthenticated and this'll be an easy way for me to ask at any point, do we actually have a logged in user?

Use Identity service in Navbar Login controller

Okay, now let's go back to our login controller

navbarLoginController.js 

angular.module('app').controller('navbarLoginController', function ($scope, $http, notifier, identity){  
  $scope.signin = function(username, password){
    $http.post('/login', {username:username, password:password}).then(function(response){
      if(response.data.success){
        identity.currentUser = response.data.user;
        notifier.notify('You have successfully signed in!');
      }else{
        notifier.notify('Username/Password combination incorrect');
      }

});

[1] Now I need to go and the identity service as a dependency

[5] when the user successfully logs in, let's take that identity service and set the current user = response.data.user

Include scripts to app

Of course we're going to have to add script tags for those files, so we'll go to our scripts and add identity and we'll add the notifier. We also need Toaster in here.
