script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/common/notifier.js")
Test in the browser

So let's go back to our browser and refresh and give it a try.

Put in an invalid username and we do get our popup.

I'm not really crazy about the positioning of the popup or the color, so let's go back to our code and let's fix the positioning and color of that popup by going into our style file.

site.css 

.toast-top-right{  
  top: 70px;
}

.toast-success{
  background-color: #13987e;
}

And go back and refresh.

Okay, the positioning is good and the color now matches, so I like that.

Hide form after logging in

Now let's also make the login form disappear once a user logs in.

We'll just go to this Jade file and we'll just take this whole entire form

navbar-login.jade 

div(ng-controller="navbarLoginController")  
  .row.collapse(ng-hide="identity.isAuthenticated()")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      input.form-control(placeholder="Email", ng-model="username")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      input.form-control(type="password", placeholder="password", ng-model="password")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      a.alert.button.expand(ng-click="signin(username,password)") Sign in

[2] add an ng-hide attribute and this will set to identity.isAuthenticated, taking advantage of that method that we just wrote

navbarLoginController.js 

angular.module('app').controller('navbarLoginController', function ($scope, $http, notifier, identity){  
  $scope.identity = identity;
  $scope.signin = function(username, password){
    $http.post('/login', {username:username, password:password}).then(function(response){
      if(response.data.success){
        identity.currentUser = response.data.user;
        notifier.notify('You have successfully signed in!');
      }else{
        notifier.notify('Username/Password combination incorrect');
      }
    });
  }
});

[2] and now we'll have to add that identity onto the scope so go back to the controller and the first thing we'll do here is say scope.identity = identity.

Test in the browser

And so let's go test and see how this new functionality works for us.

Refresh the page, and now the login box disappears.

Refactoring the Navbar Login controller

So let's go back to the code and I'm really not happy with what this code's doing right now because the code in the controller's really doing a couple of things.

It's handling the binding of data and the display that happens whenever a user logs in, which is what a controller should do, but

it's also actually handling the login business logic, which a controller shouldn't so.

So we're gonna refactor this and make a new service out of it by going to our account and creating a new service.

We'll call auth and name it auth.js.

Terminal 

$ touch public/app/account/auth.js

auth.js 

angular.module('app').factory('auth', function($http, identity, $q){  
  return {
    authenticateUser: function(username, password){
      var deferred = $q.defer();
      $http.post('/login', {username:username, password:password}).then(function(response){
        if(response.data.success){
          identity.currentUser = response.data.user;
          deferred.resolve(true);
        }else{
          deferred.resolve(false);
        }
      });
      return deferred.promise;
    }
  }
});

[1] This will need the http service, also the identity service, and since it's going to be communicating back with the controller, I'm gonna add in as well the q service, so I can use a promise back in the controller.

[3] Now this object that I return, I'm gonna give it one function, called authenticate.user, and that will be a function that takes in a username and password.

[7] Set the identity to the correct value

[4] so the only other thing I need to do is actually communicate back to the controller by using a promise so I'm gonna create a new deferred here

[8] and when we're successful, after we set the user, I'm going to resolve that deferred with simply a true to indicate that we were successful logging in

[19] and I'll put a false in this resolution if we were unsuccessful

[13] and then I'll return the promise for that deferred.

And now I'll go back to the navbar login controller

navbarLoginController.js 

angular.module('app').controller('navbarLoginController', function ($scope, $http, notifier, identity, auth){  
  $scope.identity = identity;
  $scope.signin = function(username, password){
    auth.authenticateUser(username, password).then(function(success){
      if(success){
        notifier.notify('You have successfully signed in!');
      }else{
        notifier.notify('Username/password combination incorrect');
      }
    });
  }
});

[1] We'll inject a reference to the auth service. We still need to bring in the identity because we still have to set it onto the scope here, but no longer will we be calling post.

[4] Instead we'll call auth.authenticate.user and pass in the username and password.

[5-6] And then we'll receive our success message and if we were successful then we'll call the notifier, telling them that that worked.

[7-8] Otherwise we'll call notifier saying that we didn't log in successfully and now we can take this code out of here

Add Auth service to scripts

Then we just need to go to scripts file and add in that auth service.

script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/account/auth.js")  
script(type="text/javascript", src="/app/common/notifier.js")
Test in browser

And now we can go back to our website and check that our functionality still works.

Refresh the page, and sign in.

Everything is still working.

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Authentication: Improving the Server Login Code
posts.html:
Over here in my routes file, this particular route, the login route,

routes.js 

var passport = require('passport');

module.exports = function(app){  
  app.get('/partials/*', function(req, res){
    res.render('./' + req.params[0]);
  });

  app.post('/login', function(req, res, next){
    var auth = passport.authenticate('local', function(err, user){
      if(err) { return next(err); }
      if(!user) { return res.send({success:false}) }
      req.logIn(user, function(err){
        if(err) { return next(err); }
        res.send({
          success: true,
          user   : user
        });
      });
    });
    auth(req, res, next);
  });

  app.get('*', function(req, res){
    res.render('index');
  });
}

is actually doing a whole bunch of logic and that's not really logic that belongs inside of a routes file.

The route itself should simply be the route and then maybe a couple of lines to handle the route, but doing a whole bunch of logic like this inside of the route just isn't very maintainable.

So I'd like to refactor this out into its own file.

So what I'm gonna do is go in to my server directory and into config and create a new file and I'll call this auth.js

Terminal 

$ touch server/config/auth.js

auth.js 

var passport = require('passport');

exports.authenticate = function(req, res, next){  
  var auth = passport.authenticate('local', function(err, user){
    if(err) { return next(err); }
    if(!user) { return res.send({success:false}) }
    req.logIn(user, function(err){
      if(err) { return next(err); }
      res.send({
        success: true,
        user   : user
      });
    });
  });
  auth(req, res, next);
};

[3] I'll have this exports a function called authenticate, and I'm just going to come back into here and grab this entire function from routes.js.

[1] Now I've got to bring in the Passport module

routes.js 

var auth = require('./auth');

module.exports = function(app){  
  app.get('/partials/*', function(req, res){
    res.render('./' + req.params[0]);
  });

  app.post('/login', auth.authenticate);

  app.get('*', function(req, res){
    res.render('index');
  });
}

[1] then I've got to go back here and I've got to bring in that new auth module, but I can remove Passport now

[8] and here I'll pass in the function auth.authenticate.

And now it makes this routes file a lot more readable.

Test in browser

So let's check our functionality by going back to the browser, refreshing, and checking that we can still log in

And our functionality's still working.

So there we've gone through and:

  • improved our authentication code
  • we've made the client track that somebody's logged in
  • and hidden the login box upon logging in.

One of the things that's really beautiful about Angular, if we go back to the code, is the fact that here in our partial, we're able to do things just based on whether or not somebody's authenticated.

navbar-login.jade 

div(ng-controller="navbarLoginController")  
  .row.collapse(ng-hide="identity.isAuthenticated()")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      input.form-control(placeholder="Email", ng-model="username")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      input.form-control(type="password", placeholder="password", ng-model="password")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      a.alert.button.expand(ng-click="signin(username,password)") Sign in

So we don't have to go into the code that does the login here in the auth service and once somebody's actually logged in we don't have to call a whole bunch of code that sets up state on the page, changes things, makes things enabled that weren't enabled.

We simply say now we have a current user and then Angular will go through and reevaluate everything and make any changes based on the fact that the state has now changed.

So if the login box should be hidden when the user is logged in, all I have to do is log in a user and I don't have to worry about communicating with some distant part of the application and saying, hey, now turn off the login box, turn on the user's profile link.

I don't have to do all that because that's automatically done for me, so long as we just use data binding to detect when state has changed.

And we don't have to refresh the page when somebody's logged in.

We can just trust that the page will be in the correct state because the state has changed somewhere else.

And this is one of the things that really makes Angular stand out among its competitors is this ability to simply change states somewhere in a common service and have that change in state cascade out everywhere without having to declare the dependencies in relationships between pieces of state.

We can simply just declare like we did in our partial, hey, if a user's logged in then they should be invisible, this other piece should be visible, etc., etc., and Angular takes care of making all those updates for us.

Module Summary

In this module we've implemented a lot of the code to make authentication work using Passport with its local strategy, but we still have more code to write before our security features are complete so in the next module we'll continue on with this effort and implement some security and authorization.

Improve Client Login CodeSecurity and Authentication

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Security and Authorization: Implementing Secure Passwords
posts.html:
Module Introduction

In this module, we are going to continue what we started in the last module by implementing some more security measures for our authentication and then implementing an authorization scheme.

Implementing Secure Passwords

In this section, we're going to implement passwords for our login, but we're going to implement them in a secure manner, so we're going to store our passwords in an encrypted manner, not in clear text.

Storing passwords in clear text should never be done.

Even if your website isn't important, and there's nothing anybody can steal by getting unauthorized access to your system, the usernames and passwords of your users are still very valuable.

Since your users are likely to use the same passwords on other sites, they could be used to gain access to other, more important sites.

Therefore, you should always store your users' passwords in an encrypted manner.

Now, there are two types of encryption:

  • One-way
  • two-way

When storing passwords, it's always best to store them in a one-way manner so that they can never be decrypted back into their original, clear text form.

This one-way encryption is called hashing.

Very basically, you start out with a clear text password and a salt.

A salt is just a randomly generated number.

You take those two pieces of data, put them into a hashing algorithm, and then what comes out is a hashed password.

This cannot be reversed back into its original form.

It's also always best to use a unique salt with each password. Using the same salt for all passwords can be a security vulnerability.

Therefore, for each user, we're going to want to store both their salt and their hashed password.

Now, there are a lot of different hashing algorithms out there. Some of them are more secure than others. The hashing that we're going to use is pretty secure, but if you're going to be doing any high-security applications, like medical or financial, then you should do more research and choose an appropriately secure encryption method.

Adding salt and hashed password to User Schema

So, we're going to begin our implementation by going to our code and adding two new fields to our user schema.

mongoose.js 

var mongoose = require('mongoose'),  
    crypto   = require('crypto');

module.exports = function(config){  
  mongoose.connect(config.db);
  var db = mongoose.connection;
  db.on('error', console.error.bind(console, 'connection error...'));
  db.once('open', function callback(){
    console.log('mydatabase db opened');
  });

  var userSchema = mongoose.Schema({
    firstName : String,
    lastName  : String,
    username  : String,
    salt      : String,
    hashed_pwd: String
  });

  var User = mongoose.model('User', userSchema);

  User.find([]).exec(function(err, collection){
    if(collection.length = 0){

      var salt, hash;

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'jimjim');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Joe',
        lastName  : 'Eames',
        username  : 'jimjim',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'bobbywes');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Bob',
        lastName  : 'Wes',
        username  : 'bobbywes',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'jamesmoe');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Moe',
        lastName  : 'James',
        username  : 'jamesmoe',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });
    }
  });
}

function createSalt(){  
  return crypto.randomBytes(128).toString('base64');
}

function hashPwd(salt, pwd){  
  var hmac = crypto.createHmac('sha1', salt);
  return hmac.udpate(pwd).digest('hex');
}

[16] We're going to add a salt field, which will also be a string

[17] and a hashed password field, again, a string.

Now that we've got these two fields inside of our schema, we need to add them to our initial users that we add to the database. But, before we can do that, we actually need to have methods that will create a salt and create a hashed password from a clear text password and a salt.

[2] So, I'm going to go up to the top and bring in the Crypto module. Crypto is the built-in cryptography module that's included with Node.

Now, I'm going to go down to the bottom of my file and create two new functions.

[60-62] The first one will be "create salt". And for this, I'm going to use the Crypto module and ask it to give me some random bytes. I want 128 of them, which makes this a pretty long salt and, therefore, increases the security of my algorithm. And, I want those in Base64 format.

[64-67] Now, I also need a function to create a hashed password. And it takes in a salt and a password.

[65] And, the first thing I do here is create an HMAC, or a hash message authentication code. It's really not important to understand what this is. This function takes two parameters. The first is the algorithm itself, which I'll choose the SHA-1 algorithm, and then the salt.

[66] Now that I've got an HMAC, I'm going to return out the HMAC after I update it with the password and then I want to call digest on that result and tell it to return out in hex form. This will give me back a hex-based representation of the result of hashing that password with that salt using the SHA-1 algorithm.

Now that I've got my functions to create a salt and hash my passwords, I'm going to go up to the sample users and I'm going to create variables for the salt and the hash.

[27,37,47] And I'll set the salt equal to a new salt

[28,38,48] and then I'll hash the password by setting hash equal to the hash password, passing in the salt that I just created and the password for the user. So for each user, I'm just going to use a password that's the same as their username, for simplicity.

[33-34,43-44,53-54] And, now I need to update the user schemas to also update the salt and the hashed password.

Regenerate Users with new Schema

And now that I got that implemented, I need to regenerate my default users so that they have the hash and the password.

So, first I need to go back to my command line, into my Mongo shell and, looking at the users, we can see they don't have their hash or their password, so I need to remove them.

Terminal 

$ mongo
MongoDB shell version: 3.0.0  
connecting to: test  
> db.users.find()
> use mydatabase
switched to db mydatabase  
> db.users.find()
{ "_id" : ObjectId("552fd0addfb7184c25ec2b5c"), "firstName" : "Joe", "lastName" : "Eames", "username" : "jimjim", "__v" : 0 }
{ "_id" : ObjectId("552fd0addfb7184c25ec2b5d"), "firstName" : "Bob", "lastName" : "Wes", "username" : "bobby", "__v" : 0 }
{ "_id" : ObjectId("552fd0addfb7184c25ec2b5e"), "firstName" : "Moe", "lastName" : "James", "username" : "jamesmoe", "__v" : 0 }
> db.users.remove({})
WriteResult({ "nRemoved" : 3 })

Go back in here and make a change and save, and that will cause nodemon to rerun the Node server, which will regenerate these users.

Go back to the command line and look at the users. And, we can see that now they actually have a salt and a hashed password stored in their document.

Terminal 

> db.users.find()
{ "_id" : ObjectId("5531096ee63803c00ba22281"), "firstName" : "Joe", "lastName" : "Eames", "username" : "jimjim", "salt" : "aWJ9hvduuxesy7hNdiRHmLFiyrhycHvRRj7ISdSY5AJmFtD56GMHCKXRFbtuIS7w/liSfOEXbWQdB0Ckv3LI6tV96l4gR6BwNweRIhX+FO+EtxSnFAGQYWS8+RjGs94bKIClltL+YiQokwtJw8neryllqpvJcwkvtZ3NtnZId/8=", "hashed_pwd" : "0eadb57fab4c3250ce86833131381751c61b7b2d", "__v" : 0 }
{ "_id" : ObjectId("5531096ee63803c00ba22282"), "firstName" : "Bob", "lastName" : "Wes", "username" : "bobbywes", "salt" : "fD1N6JVVzxlUvpoOgayPlONQhi+9Q5M4kPV3mTMYNEnOaKmHJD3IQYiRqzKzrKOlJt0G//H8bDZovKQbAYVYwxyEa3ymET720uwqzHjmY4RJF4ACqImlYxySohMM1N495eorbMc0sv3guP8kQBaSIHpKKtWVZkvWGy2BDJgl2U4=", "hashed_pwd" : "c55ef452077febea958878520b580a536f38e370", "__v" : 0 }
{ "_id" : ObjectId("5531096ee63803c00ba22283"), "firstName" : "Moe", "lastName" : "James", "username" : "jamesmoe", "salt" : "yvtjqf+mjGxaJnluUuYYEmHx4kKjMzxbgQZXzTEw2D6n4QypJLAbnZHnaGPqsPDu6+1kIRY39JQvAg9MD5JJ59TE2hi+PpVbOtI7yef1m6zNg3IundJDvf/k6Tm2q+cRE/51zTt+VbKAvHGDCb+tUezzJyTj0wEzNijuoXyCG/A=", "hashed_pwd" : "46d1153445ae32e47271b27ced7e6b04776aa413", "__v" : 0 }

Now, another small security flaw that you should be aware of is the fact that we're sending the entire user object down to the client whenever somebody logs in.

Again, these hashed passwords are really quite secure, but there's no need to be sending the salt and the hashed password down to the client.

We're not going to fix this in our implementation for this course, but it is something you should be aware of and, in a production implementation, you should remove these fields from the data that you send down to the client.

And now that we got our data ready, let's change our authentication algorithm. Back in my server.js code

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);

var User = mongoose.model('User');  
passport.use(new LocalStrategy(  
  function(username, password, done){
    User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
      if(user && user.authenticate(password)){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  }
));

passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){  
  if(user) {
    done(null, user._id);
  }
});

passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){  
  User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
    if(user){
      return done(null, user);
    } else {
      return done(null, false);
    }
  });
});

require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

[19] I'm going to go down into my local strategy and I'm going to change those methods so it not only checks to see if the user actually exists, but it also checks to make sure the user is authenticated. And, by calling user.authenticate, that's going to be a method that I'll create on my user schema. And, I'll pass in the password. And, this checks to make sure that the password is authentic for that user.

So, let's go back to our Mongoose code

mongoose.js 

var mongoose = require('mongoose'),  
    crypto   = require('crypto');

module.exports = function(config){  
  mongoose.connect(config.db);
  var db = mongoose.connection;
  db.on('error', console.error.bind(console, 'connection error...'));
  db.once('open', function callback(){
    console.log('mydatabase db opened');
  });

  var userSchema = mongoose.Schema({
    firstName : String,
    lastName  : String,
    username  : String,
    salt      : String,
    hashed_pwd: String
  });

  userSchema.methods = {
    authenticate: function(passwordToMatch){
      return hashPwd(this.salt, passwordToMatch) = = = this.hashed_pwd;
    }
  }

  var User = mongoose.model('User', userSchema);

  User.find([]).exec(function(err, collection){
    if(collection.length = 0){

      var salt, hash;

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'jimjim');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Joe',
        lastName  : 'Eames',
        username  : 'jimjim',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'bobbywes');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Bob',
        lastName  : 'Wes',
        username  : 'bobbywes',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'jamesmoe');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Moe',
        lastName  : 'James',
        username  : 'jamesmoe',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });
    }
  });
}

function createSalt(){  
  return crypto.randomBytes(128).toString('base64');
}

function hashPwd(salt, pwd){  
  var hmac = crypto.createHmac('sha1', salt);
  hmac.setEncoding('hex');
  hmac.write(pwd);
  hmac.end();
  return hmac.read();
}

[20-24] let's go over to our schema and let's add a new method to it. We'll do that by setting the methods property equal to an object that has the methods in there that I want.

[21] And, I want to add that authenticate method. And, I want to take the password that they're trying to match, hash it, and compare it to the current user's hashed password. So, I'll pass it into the hashed password function, passing in the current user's salt and the password to match, and check that that is equal to the current user's hashed password.

And now, we should be able to authenticate a user's attempt to sign-in based on not just their username, but also their password.

So, we'll go back to our website and refresh it. And, let's try to login with an invalid password, but a valid username.

But, let's give it the valid password.

And it successfully signs us in.

And, that is how to implement secure passwords using hashing.

posts.html:
Now that a user can login, we want them to be able to logout.

So, the first step to doing that is implementing the UI for logging out.

So, on our page:

  • when a user logs in,
  • in place of the sign-in form, we'll place a sign-out link.

We'll implement this as an area that shows the user's name and allows them to select sign-out from a drop-down.

navbar-login.jade 

div(ng-controller="navbarLoginController")  
  .row.collapse(ng-hide="identity.isAuthenticated()")

[12] And then within this ul, we'll have one list item. We'll give that the class drop-down.

[14] Then on-click, we'll call the sign-out method and we'll have the text that says "Sign-Out".

So, now that we've specified the drop-down, it's not going to work because we're not including the JavaScript file, which actually makes the drop-downs work.

So, let's go to the scripts file and add a reference to that.

scripts.jade 

script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/jquery/dist/jquery.js")  
script(type="text/javascript", src="/vendor/toastr/toastr.js")

[3,4] We'll put it here right underneath Toastr.

Test in the browser

Now, let's take a quick second and see if our new functionality is working.

I'll sign in.

And now there's this drop-down that shows me the sign-out link.

Implement sign-out on the client

The next thing we need to do now that we're displaying the sign-out link is to actually make it do something on the client, which would be to call back to the server and tell the server to sign-out.

So, let's go back to our code and we're going to open up our navbar login controller.

navbarLoginController.js 

angular.module('app').controller('navbarLoginController', function ($scope, $http, notifier, identity, auth, $location){  
  $scope.identity = identity;

  $scope.signin = function(username, password){
    auth.authenticateUser(username, password).then(function(success){
      if(success){
        notifier.notify('You have successfully signed in!');
      }else{
        notifier.notify('Username/password combination incorrect');
      }
    });
  };

  $scope.signout = function(){
    auth.logoutUser().then(function(){
      $scope.username = "";
      $scope.password = "";
      notifier.notify('You have successfully signed out!');
      $location.path('/');
    });
  };
});

[14] And, we're going to add a new method called "Sign-Out"

[15] and we're going to implement the communication with the server inside of our auth service. So, here we'll tell the auth service to logout the user.

[16,17] And then, we need to allow for you just to log back in under a different identity, so let's clear out the username and password box.

[18] And, let's notify the user that they successfully logged out.

[19] And then, just in case the user has navigated to something that they no longer have access to, let's redirect them back to the Home page.

[1] Now, I'll need to also include the $location service as a dependency.

Implement logout in Auth service

And, we need to go into our auth service and implement the logout user function.

auth.js 

angular.module('app').factory('auth', function($http, identity, $q){  
  return {
    authenticateUser: function(username, password){
      var deferred = $q.defer();
      $http.post('/login', {username:username, password:password}).then(function(response){
        if(response.data.success){
          identity.currentUser = response.data.user;
          deferred.resolve(true);
        }else{
          deferred.resolve(false);
        }
      });
      return deferred.promise;
    },
    logoutUser: function(){
      var deferred = $q.defer();
      $http.post('/logout', {logout:true}).then(function(){
        identity.currentUser = undefined;
        deferred.resolve();
      });
      return deferred.promise;
    }
  }
});

[16] And inside here, we'll do the same thing we did with authenticate and create a deferred.

[17] And then, we'll POST to the server. And, we have to give Angular a body, otherwise, it will turn this POST into a GET. So, I'm just going to send up an object that has a logout property set to "true", even though I don't need to really check that on the server.

[18] And then when that returns, I can set the identity to an undefined value

[19] and then we'll resolve the deferred.

[21] And, lastly, we'll return that deferred's promise.

Implement route on the server side

But, we also need to implement the route on the server side. So, we'll go into our routes file

routes.js 

var auth = require('./auth');

module.exports = function(app){  
  app.get('/partials/*', function(req, res){
    res.render('./' + req.params[0]);
  });

  app.post('/login', auth.authenticate);
  app.post('/logout', function(req, res){
    req.logout(); // function added by Passport module
    res.end();
  });

  app.get('*', function(req, res){
    res.render('index');
  });
}

[9] we've got our login route, so right after that, we'll put our logout route.

[10] And inside here, we'll call the logout function on the request. That function was added by the Passport module.

[11] And then, we'll just end the response.

Normally, you would also redirect on the server, but since our client is handling all views, there's no reason to redirect at this point.

Test in the browser

And after saving those changes, we can go and see the new functionality in our application.

We'll login again. And, this time I'll click the Sign-Out link.

And, I got the message that we've successfully signed out, and our login box is back and it's blank. And so, there, we've implemented the sign-out functionality for our application.

Implementing Secure PasswordsPersistent Login

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Security and Authorization: Persisting Login between Page Refreshes
posts.html:
Our application's login is working pretty well now. We can both sign-in and sign-out. But, we have a problem with our login. Once we sign-in, if we refresh our page, the page no longer remembers that we're signed in again.

The client-side code is asking us to sign-in because it doesn't know who the current user is, but the server does.

We can prove that by adding in some middleware into server.js.

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);

var User = mongoose.model('User');  
passport.use(new LocalStrategy(  
  function(username, password, done){
    User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
      if(user && user.authenticate(password)){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  }
));

app.use(function(req, res, next){  
  console.log(req.user);
  next();
});

passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){  
  if(user) {
    done(null, user._id);
  }
});

passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){  
  User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
    if(user){
      return done(null, user);
    } else {
      return done(null, false);
    }
  });
});

require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

[28] Let's go down after we declare the local strategy and add in some middleware.

[29] We're going to print out request.user

[30] and then just continue on our merry way with the next() function.

Proving that the server knows

Now, let's go to the browser and we'll refresh the page. And then, we'll login. And, going back and looking at the console, we can see that it's printed out "undefined" several times for the current user, then it handles the login POST.

Now, let's go back and refresh the page.

Looking back, we can see that it's printed out the current user several times, and the current user it printed out is actually a real object, and that's the Joe Eames user.

So, our server knows who the current user is, yet the client has no idea.

So, it's time to adjust that problem and let the client know who the current user is whenever the page is requested.

Now, I have a couple of ways that we can solve this problem.

The first one is:

  1. After the page has been run
  2. we can have Angular call back to the server
  3. and ask if there is a currently authenticated user.
  4. If so, it would bring it back
  5. and then set it into the current user property
  6. and then our display would update.

But, there's a couple of drawbacks with this approach.

The first one is there'll be a little bit of a delay since that call is asynchronous, but the page is going to be rendered, but we're going to be waiting for the server to tell us whether or not there's a current user. Therefore, we could also have some flicker in our display.

The second drawback is that it adds one more call. Therefore, the performance on our page is going to be degraded a little bit, and this is unnecessary.

The other approach that we could take is simply to have the server, as it sends the index page down to us, also send down the current user if there is one.

This is known as bootstrapping data and, thankfully, with Node and JADE this is very simple.

So, let's go back to our code and we're going to go into our layout file

layout.jade 

doctype  
html  
  head
    link(href="/favicon.ico", rel="shortcut icon", type="image/x-icon")
    link(rel="stylesheet", href="/vendor/foundation/css/foundation.css")
    link(rel="stylesheet", href="/vendor/toastr/toastr.css")
    link(rel="stylesheet", href="/css/site.css")
  body(ng-app='app')
    include currentUser
    block main-content
    include scripts

[9] I'm going to add another include in here. The very first thing in the body is going to be another include called "current user".

Now, I've got to go into my server code, into my includes, and create that file.

Terminal 

$ touch public/app/common/currentUser.jade

And inside this file, we'll create a script tag that will create a global variable that will have the current user, which we received from that request.user property that we looked at earlier.

Unfortunately, the JADE template doesn't have access to the request object, so we can't just grab request.user off of it.

We've actually got to pass it into the page.

So, let's first go back to our server.js and let's delete the middleware that we created.

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);

var User = mongoose.model('User');  
passport.use(new LocalStrategy(  
  function(username, password, done){
    User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
      if(user && user.authenticate(password)){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  }
));

passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){  
  if(user) {
    done(null, user._id);
  }
});

passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){  
  User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
    if(user){
      return done(null, user);
    } else {
      return done(null, false);
    }
  });
});

require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

Then, we'll go to our routes file.

routes.js 

var auth = require('./auth');

module.exports = function(app){  
  app.get('/partials/*', function(req, res){
    res.render('./' + req.params[0]);
  });

  app.post('/login', auth.authenticate);
  app.post('/logout', function(req, res){
    req.logout(); // function added by Passport module
    res.end();
  });

  app.get('*', function(req, res){
    res.render('index', {
      bootstrappedUser: req.user
    });
  });
}

[16] We'll add the request.user as a piece of data that's passed to the index page. So, down where I rendered the index page, I'll add a second parameter, which is an object, and I'm going to call this object "bootstrapped user", and that's going to be set to the value of the request.user.

Current User template

Now that that data's available to the template, we can go back into our current user template and we can check and see if that data exists.

And that way, we won't write out any extra HTML if there's no authenticated user.

currentUser.jade 

if !!bootstrappedUser  
  script.
    window.bootstrappedUserObject = !(JSON.stringify(bootstrappedUser))

[2] We'll create a script tag and we'll use JADE's line continuation '.'.

[3] And here, we'll set the global variable to contain that bootstrapped user object. Now, I want to make sure this is a fairly unique name, so I'm going to stick it in a variable called "bootstrapped user object". And then, I'll use JADE string interpolation. And, I want to put that bootstrapped user here, but I want it in JSON form, so I'm going to call "JSON.stringify" and pass in the bootstrapped user.

  • So, again, this is the name of the variable that has been created by our template.
  • Bootstrapped user is an object that's only available on the server
  • and only available at the time that it interprets the JADE file
  • and turns the template into actual HTML.
  • The script that's going to get written out is going to have a variable called "bootstrapped user object"
  • that's going to be set to the JSON form of the bootstrapped user.

And, at this point, for any page requests that already have an authenticated user, we're going to have a script tag that contains our bootstrapped user object.

Verify in browser

Now, since we've made some changes to our server-side JS files, our server is restarted, so the server no longer has a currently authenticated user.

So if we go back to the browser, and refresh the page, now we have the correct client-side code and the login boxes are showing because there's no currently authenticated user.

So, let's login and then we'll refresh the page.

And, the login boxes are showing back up because Angular doesn't know about a current user, but if we look at the source of the page, we can see our authenticated user has been stuck here into the bootstrapped user object variable, with all the data that a user has on the server.

Putting User data into identity service

So, our next step is to take all this data and put it into the current user on the identity service that we created so that Angular will know about the user.

So, let's close this down and we'll go back to our code and we'll open up our identity service. And, inside here we'll add a little bit of code to check for that bootstrapped user object.

identity.js 

angular.module('app').factory('identity', function($window){  
  var currentUser;
  if(!!$window.bootstrappedUserObject){
    currentUser = $window.bootstrappedUserObject;
  }
  return {
    currentUser: currentUser,
    isAuthenticated: function(){
      return !!this.currentUser;
    }
  }
});

[1] Now, the bootstrapped user object is a global variable that's available on the window, so the first thing I want to do is bring in a* window dependency*.

Now, I can always just use the global variable window, but at test time, that means I've got to set up a global variable on my window object. It's much better to use Angular's dollar sign window service, which allows me to mock it when it comes time to test this object.

[2] So, I'm going to create the current user variable and I'll just leave its default value as undefined.

[3] And, then I'll check to see if the bootstrapped user object is available on the window.

[4] If that object does exist, I'm going to assign it to the current user.

[7] And now, down here we'll recreate the current user property. I simply set that to that current user variable. So, it will still be undefined if the bootstrapped user object doesn't exist, but if it does exist, then it will be the value of the bootstrapped user object.

Test in the browser

So, let's save that change and let's go back to the browser and refresh the page.

And, then we'll login.

Now at this point, our server has restarted itself because Node Mon has noticed the change to the Angular JavaScript file that we changed.

Unfortunately, it didn't need to restart the server because we just changed client-side code, but that is one of the drawbacks of Nodemon is, because it's a JavaScript file, it doesn't know whether it's a server-side or client-side file, so it goes ahead and restarts the server anyway.

So, we'll have to login.

And now that we're logged in, we can refresh the page.

And you can see that our login boxes are still hidden and we show who the currently logged in user is and their drop-down that lets us sign-out.

And, no matter how many times we refresh the page, since the server knows about the current authenticated user, the client now knows about it. So, there we have successfully bootstrapped the data for the current user to the page and brought it into Angular so that Angular now knows who the currently authenticated user is.

Adding Signout FunctionalityRefactoring Server Authenication Code

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Security and Authorization: Refactoring Server Authentication Code
posts.html:
In the server.js file, my code has become cluttered up again as we've added an authentication.

server.js 

var express     = require('express'),  
  mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
  passport      = require('passport'),
  LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy;

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';

var app = express();

var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);

var User = mongoose.model('User');  
passport.use(new LocalStrategy(  
  function(username, password, done){
    User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
      if(user && user.authenticate(password)){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  }
));

passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){  
  if(user) {
    done(null, user._id);
  }
});

passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){  
  User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
    if(user){
      return done(null, user);
    } else {
      return done(null, false);
    }
  });
});

require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

Another way of identifying this problem is seeing that there's two different levels of abstraction going on.

[12,13] The higher level is these lines here where we simply call out to config, Express, Mongoose.

At this level, we're simply telling our code "configure Express, configure Mongoose, etc".

[15-42] Then we drop down a level into more details where we configure Passport.

[44] Then we come back up a level as we run our route configuration.

Creating passport.js

So, I'd like to fix that and have the server.js code run from the same level of abstraction throughout the entire file.

In order to do that, I'm going to do the same thing we did before by extracting the Passport code out into its own config file, which I'll call "Passport".

Terminal 

$ touch server/config/passport.js

passport.js 

var passport      = require('passport'),  
    mongoose      = require('mongoose'),
    LocalStrategy = require('passport-local').Strategy,
    User          = mongoose.model('User');

module.exports = function(){  
  passport.use(new LocalStrategy(
    function(username, password, done){
      User.findOne({username:username}).exec(function(err, user) {
        if(user && user.authenticate(password)){
          return done(null, user);
        } else {
          return done(null, false);
        }
      });
    }
  ));

  passport.serializeUser(function(user, done){
    if(user) {
      done(null, user._id);
    }
  });

  passport.deserializeUser(function(id, done){
    User.findOne({_id:id}).exec(function(err, user){
      if(user){
        return done(null, user);
      } else {
        return done(null, false);
      }
    });
  });

}

[7-33] I'm going to go back into my server code and I'll grab the deserialize and serialize and the local strategy code, cut that out, go over into Passport, set my module.exports, and paste in that code.

[1-2] Now, I need to go through and figure out what this code needs in order to work. So, I can see it needs Mongoose and Passport, so let's bring in those modules.

[3] We also need the local strategy object, which comes out of the passport-local model.

[4] And, lastly, we need this user object. I want to pull it outside of the exports and put it right up here.

And now, this file has everything it needs to run.

Update server.js

So, let's go back to our server file

server.js 

var express = require('express');

var env = process.env.NODE_ENV = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development';  
var app = express();  
var config = require('./server/config/config')[env];

require('./server/config/express')(app, config);  
require('./server/config/mongoose')(config);  
require('./server/config/passport')();  
require('./server/config/routes')(app);

app.listen(config.port);  
console.log('Listening on port ' + config.port + '...');

[9] let's add in another line that will run Passport. And we don't need to pass it any parameters.

[1] And at this point, we can go up and clean up the modules that we no longer need inside of this file, which include Mongoose, Passport, and the local strategy.

Verify in the browser

And, now our refactoring is complete and we can verify it in the browser. Refresh the page, sign-in, and then refresh the page again. And, I'm still signed in.

All right, and now our server.js file looks a lot cleaner and much easier to read and understand.

Persisting LoginImplementing Clientside Authorization

posts.title: Building Angular.js and Node.js with the MEAN stack - Security and Authorization: Implementing Clientside Authorization
posts.html:
Now that we have our authentication working, we're going to add authorization.

Authentication tells us whether or not a user has been logged in successfully, but authorization tells us whether or not a user can access certain areas or perform certain functions.

Passport only implements authentication and not authorization, so we'll have to do our authorization by hand.

Our authorization implementation is going to follow the standard method of using roles. So, we're going to give our users roles.

By default, the user will be a standard user unless they have the role of admin, in which case, they'll be an admin.

We'll do that by going over to our Mongoose file

mongoose.js 

var mongoose = require('mongoose'),  
    crypto   = require('crypto');

module.exports = function(config){  
  mongoose.connect(config.db);
  var db = mongoose.connection;
  db.on('error', console.error.bind(console, 'connection error...'));
  db.once('open', function callback(){
    console.log('mydatabase db opened');
  });

  var userSchema = mongoose.Schema({
    firstName : String,
    lastName  : String,
    username  : String,
    salt      : String,
    hashed_pwd: String,
    roles     : [String]
  });

  userSchema.methods = {
    authenticate: function(passwordToMatch){
      return hashPwd(this.salt, passwordToMatch) = this.hashed_pwd;
    }
  }

  var User = mongoose.model('User', userSchema);

  User.find([]).exec(function(err, collection){
    if(collection.length = 0){

      var salt, hash;

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'jimjim');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Joe',
        lastName  : 'Eames',
        username  : 'jimjim',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash,
        roles: ['admin']
      });

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'bobbywes');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Bob',
        lastName  : 'Wes',
        username  : 'bobbywes',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash,
        roles: []
      });

      salt = createSalt();
      hash = hashPwd(salt, 'jamesmoe');
      User.create({
        firstName : 'Moe',
        lastName  : 'James',
        username  : 'jamesmoe',
        salt      : salt,
        hashed_pwd: hash
      });
    }
  });
}

function createSalt(){  
  return crypto.randomBytes(128).toString('base64');
}

function hashPwd(salt, pwd){  
  var hmac = crypto.createHmac('sha1', salt);
  hmac.setEncoding('hex');
  hmac.write(pwd);
  hmac.end();
  return hmac.read();
}

[18] Inside of the schema, we're going to add another property to our users. This is going to be their roles.

We're going to keep our implementation simple.

We're just going to give our users an array of strings that indicates which roles that they have.

And this syntax is how we indicate that to Mongoose.

[42] Now that we have our roles property set up, let's go down to our initial users and add the role data to them.

Our first user, Joe, we'll make an admin.

So, we'll add the roles property and give him the string of admin.

[53] Our next user, John Papa, will be a typical user, so we'll give him the roles property, but we'll just give him an empty array.

[58] And, our last user, Dan, will also be a typical user. And this time, we won't modify his record and we won't add the roles property.

Getting client-side code to determine roles

And, now that we have the authorization information inside of our user schema, we need to go and add the ability for our client-side code to determine whether or not a user is an admin.

Now, there's a couple of ways that we could do this.

We could just add in a function that checks the user's roles property and looks for an array called "admin" and just call that everywhere we need to determine whether or not a user is an admin.

But, it would be much better if we actually added in a bit of modeling.

The easiest way to do that in Angular is to implement resources.

So, let's go into our public directory, into our app, and into our account, and let's create a user resource object.

I'm going to name this "user.js".

Terminal 

$ touch public/app/account/myUser.js

myUser.js 

angular.module('app').factory('myUser', function($resource){  
  var UserResource = $resource('/api/users/:id', {_id: "@id"});

  UserResource.prototype.isAdmin = function(){
    return this.roles && this.roles.indexOf('admin') > -1;
  }

  return UserResource;
});

[1] This is going to be a service(factory).

[1] And, I'm going to bring in the $resource dependency.

[2] And, I'll create a variable called "User Resource", which will be created by calling the resource function, passing in the URL to our users.

Now at this point, we don't have any routes established in order to RESTfully access users, but we're going to go ahead and set our URL to the route that we'll create sometime in the future when we need to access our users in a RESTful manner.

And, that will be api/users and then the ID. And then, we'll tell Angular what the ID is.

And now, we've got our resource created.

[4] Let's add a new method to that resource that will tell whether or not that user is an admin. This will add the "isAdmin" method onto every instance of a user resource.

[8] And then, finally, we just return that resource object.

Now, you may be wondering why we created a user resource when we're not accessing our users in a RESTful way.

The reason is, we can still create instances of this class on the client whenever we need a user, and there are two places where we do that.

One, where we log the user in, which is an "auth".

auth.js 

angular.module('app').factory('auth', function($http, identity, $q, myUser){  
  return {
    authenticateUser: function(username, password){
      var deferred = $q.defer();
      $http.post('/login', {username:username, password:password}).then(function(response){
        if(response.data.success){
          var user = new myUser();
          angular.extend(user, response.data.user);
          identity.currentUser = user;
          deferred.resolve(true);
        }else{
          deferred.resolve(false);
        }
      });
      return deferred.promise;
    },
    logoutUser: function(){
      var deferred = $q.defer();
      $http.post('/logout', {logout:true}).then(function(){
        identity.currentUser = undefined;
        deferred.resolve();
      });
      return deferred.promise;
    }
  }
});

[1] We'll need to bring in the "user" dependency.

[7] So, let's switch this so that it takes the data from the response and creates a user resource class out of it. We'll do that by creating a new instance of the user resource.

[8] And then, we call angular.extend, passing in the user, and then the user data from the response, and that will take the data that comes back from the HTTP POST and add it into the user object that we created.

[9] And then, here, we just set the current user equal to that user object.

And now, the current user object will have an "isAdmin" function.

The other place where we create a user object by hand is in the identity class when we checked for bootstrapped user data. And here, we'll do essentially the same thing.

identity.js 

angular.module('app').factory('identity', function($window, myUser){  
  var currentUser;
  if(!!$window.bootstrappedUserObject){
    currentUser = new myUser();
    angular.extend(currentUser, $window.bootstrappedUserObject);
  }
  return {
    currentUser: currentUser,
    isAuthenticated: function(){
      return !!this.currentUser;
    }
  }
});

[1] We'll bring in that "user" service

[4] here we'll set current user equal to a new instance of that resource.

[5] And then, here, we'll just extend that object with the bootstrap data.

Recognizing an admin

And, now that our client-side knows whether or not a user is an admin, what are we going to do with that knowledge?

Well, let's create a menu item on the drop-down box for a logged-in user that will take them to an admin page for users if they're an admin, and doesn't display if they're not.

So, let's open up our navbar-login partial

  .row.collapse(ng-hide="identity.isAuthenticated()")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      input.form-control(placeholder="Email", ng-model="username")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      input.form-control(type="password", placeholder="password", ng-model="password")
    .large-4.small-4.columns
      a.alert.button.expand(ng-click="signin(username,password)") Sign in

  li.has-dropdown(ng-show="identity.isAuthenticated()")
    a(href="#") {{ identity.currentUser.firstName + " " + identity.currentUser.lastName }}
    ul.dropdown
      li(ng-show="identity.currentUser.isAdmin()")
        a(href="/admin/user") User Admin
      li
        a(href="", ng-click="signout()") Sign Out

[14] and this user admin page will be at the URL /admin/user, and we'll name it "user admin".

[13] And, we only want this item to show if the user is an admin.
